—I was making a general point about declining standards in the Parliament and used as an example something that obviously offended members of the Australian Labor Party. I regret that they have such sensitivity on this matter. I want to deal with the fact that in a general discussion on Sunday the leading Australian members of the Press Gallery said they regarded the Treasurer (Mr Keating) as the outstanding parliamentary performer for the latest session. I want to draw the attention of honourable senators to the staggering difference between what would in normal terms be regarded as outstanding performance in the chamber-in other words, ability, determination and the capacity to argue and present a sound case-and the habits and behaviour of the Treasurer, who achieved this accolade. I quote, in great length if I may, the sort of invective that the Treasurer has consistently used to achieve this accolade from the Gallery: `Those dummies and dimwits'; `that dimwitted members of the Opposition'; `they are jokes-absolute jokes'; `those dummies opposite should just shut up'; `some of the mugs on the other side'; `don't be so damned stupid'; `the clowns opposite'; `the blockheads opposite'; and `a swill, a pig sty, and that is the limit of their capacity'. He is talking about the Opposition. I continue: `the honourable members opposite want to be sleazebags'; `damn them for the cheats they are'; `you ought to be bloody well ashamed of yourselves'; `you are frauds'; `you people are beneath contempt'; `you are an abject insult to every decent moral member of the Parliament'; `fraud and humbug'; `they are irrelevant, useless and immoral'.
—Hear, hear!

—Hear, hear! I hear. I am talking about the standards that are now acceptable in this Parliament, and another Minister in this place regards them as acceptable. `He is a leading member of the ratpack', says Mr Keating; `Coalition members have always been cheats, cheats, cheats, and will always be cheats, cheats, cheats, and always defend cheat, cheats, cheats'; `the blackguards on the front bench opposite'; `You boxhead, you would not know. You are flat out counting past ten'; `Shut up! `Sit down and shut up you big pig; `Why do you not shut up, you clown?' `This man has a criminal intellect'; `I would not trust him with a jam jar full of 5c bits'; `the jokers opposite'; `Business thinks they are mugs and hill-billies'; and `While all the fiscal and tax harlots opposite'.

SPEECH.PARA: That is an example of the style of a man who is regarded by the media as an outstanding parliamentary performer. It is a style which is disgraceful; it is a style which demeans the Parliament, and it is a style which senators opposite, members of the Government, find attractive and support. It depresses me that the media finds this kind of style attractive enough to give him a good run, but I will say of Michelle Grattan that in her article on the annual awards for the Class of `85, she says of Paul Keating:

`Dripping with political style, but please, Bob, ask him to watch his language. He is going over the top in Parliament-`sleazebags', `harlots'-and the corridors reverberate with unprintable Keatingisms.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should hear him in Cabinet.
—`You should hear him in Cabinet', the Minister says, and I believe it.
—You will never be in Cabinet.

—No; I will never be in Cabinet with Paul Keating and I am proud of that. I would not want to be in a Cabinet with a man of such status, such standing, such contempt as he shows for the parliamentary process and the proper behaviour that should exist in this Parliament. We have this kind of behaviour now intruding into this chamber. We have heard today from the expert in this area, Senator Walsh, his persistent personal abuse, and we have heard Senator Grimes consistently behaving in this way. Surely if we are going to be an effective chamber we should be dealing with issues, not personalities.
—Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is concluded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform honourable senators that Senator Gietzelt will not be here at Question Time. Any questions to be directed to him should be directed to me.

ANSWER.PARA: INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I do not think he is in the chamber.
—Ask the question anyway. It is 2 p.m. It is Question Time.

—I refer the Minister to his Government's decision to replace the commencement grant scheme for industry research with tax concessions for companies spending more than $20,000 on research and development. As the majority of commencement grants were under $20,000, does the Minister agree that this new scheme will effectively prevent many small businesses from qualifying for government assistance in the important area of industry research? In the light of widespread concern in the small business community over the impending abolition of the commencement grant scheme, will the Minister advise whether his Government will reverse its decision to wind up the scheme after 30 June next year?
—The good senator seems to have disappeared from the face of the earth at the moment.
—He should be here for Question Time.

—Of course he should be here. I will find out why he is not. Neither Senator Walsh nor I have the information or the skill to answer that question, so I will refer it to Senator Button when and if he turns up.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether his attention has been drawn to claims published in Monday's Advertiser newspaper that `Labor is pushing your interest rates through the ceiling'. Has he also seen a claim by Liberal Opposition Leader Howard that promises made by Mr Hawke and Mr Bannon about the present ceiling on housing loan interest rates were `worthless'? Can the Minister say whether there is any basis in fact to these claims?

—There is no basis of fact in the advertisements the Liberal Party is running in South Australia. Senator Bolkus is absolutely correct about that. He is correct also, as far as I know, in what he said about Mr Howard and--
—Olsen.

—Yes, that is his name. I am glad that the Labor Party knows his name, even though evidently the Federal Leader of the Liberal Party does not. He gets him confused with Mr Bannon, although the difference between the two should be very clear to him by next Sunday morning-indeed, probably on Saturday night. The Advertiser newspaper has reported the things to which Senator Bolkus referred, but of course there is no truth in either of those claims. In fact, as I said in Question Time, I think last Monday, and repeated on a previous occasion, the Treasurer gave firm assurances some weeks ago that this Government will not deregulate housing interest rates. By contrast, of course, a Liberal government would. Mr Howard said in the House of Representatives on 13 September that a Liberal government would do that. When Mr Howard was Treasurer, he lifted the ceiling on housing loan interest rates by 3 per cent on three separate occasions within 18 months. If a Liberal government were to be elected we could expect interest rates on housing loans to go up by another 3 per cent probably, just as they went up by 3 per cent in the last 18 months of Mr Howard's treasurership. Contrary, of course, to the advertisements and all the other wild claims that have been made and published in the Adelaide Advertiser, home mortgage interest rates would undoubtedly be increased if Liberal policy, as expounded by the Liberal Party Leader, Mr Howard, were ever implemented. As I have previously noted, the South Australian Premier, Mr Bannon-he is the Premier, not the Opposition Leader, as Mr Howard appears to think-has already pointed out that the effect of the deregulation of bank interest rates for housing loans would add about $70 a month to the repayment obligations of the typical borrower. That is the sort of slug which can be expected if Liberal policy is implemented.
—Senator Bjelke-Petersen, it might be helpful if you repeated your question now that Senator Button is here.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I refer the Minister to the Government's decision to replace the commencement grant scheme for industry research with tax concessions for companies spending more than $20,000 on research and development. As the majority of commencement grants were under $20,000, does the Minister agree that this new scheme will effectively prevent many small businesses from qualifying for government assistance in the important area of industry research? In the light of widespread concern in the small business community over the impending abolition of the commencement grant scheme, will the Minister advise whether his Government will reverse its decision to wind up the scheme after 30 June next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no question of the Government reversing any decision. We have not made such a decision as Senator Bjelke-Petersen referred to in her question. What the Government has done is to introduce a 150 per cent tax deduction in respect of research and development done by companies in Australia as a broad incentive to industry generally. It may be that there are a number of categories of companies which would not be able to avail themselves of that incentive. For example, there may be a number of small high technology companies which may not have sufficient cash flow or may not be generating profits. Those companies would be unable to claim the tax incentive.

ANSWER.PARA: We are looking to have two complementary schemes, one being the general tax incentive available to all business and, alongside that, a revised form of the Australian industrial research and development incentives scheme-AIRDIS-which is what Senator Bjelke-Petersen is asking about. It is true that that scheme expires under a sunset clause in the legislation on 30 June next year, but it will be replaced by a scheme which will work to a similar purpose but which will be more closely targeted to the interests of small business and companies which do not have sufficient cash flow to take advantage of the tax incentive. So the two things will mesh together. They will provide the best research and development incentive scheme that this country has ever had--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—I say that advisedly. Senator Durack laughs, for goodness sake. He took part in a government--
—Everything is the best that ever was.

—Pretty well, but let us deal with the issue in question. The honourable senator presided in government over this country for a period of eight years in which millions and millions of dollars of taxpayers' money were spent on various forms of research and development incentives. What happened in those eight years? Research and development in Australia went down in the private sector. It went down all the time. The reason it went down was that the system of incentives was wrong. The previous Government never had any system for evaluating the incentives which were in place and the results got worse and worse. I am saying that the system of incentives for research and development which this Government will have in place by the beginning of next year-the 150 per cent tax deduction, the revised form of the industrial research and development scheme, plus the existence of investment companies under the management and investment companies scheme, the MIC scheme, to assist new companies to raise venture capital-will together provide the best, most comprehensive and relevant system of incentives this country has had. Senator Durack might legitimately chide me and the Government about some shortcomings which he perceives that we have. I think that is quite legitimate. But I think he missed his mark in picking this example.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I noted the reported speech of the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia yesterday in which he said that the pace of growth in the economy needed to be slowed a little and that the Board of the Reserve Bank has confirmed this week that the very firm current stance on monetary policy will continue. In the light of the Treasurer's statement this week that if for some reason the Government were to become convinced that the overall policy response to the depreciation of the dollar was not the correct one it obviously would not stand idly by and let monetary policy take the full brunt, I ask: What revisions have been made to the projections in the current Budget? Have preparations commenced for a mini-Budget early next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —No provisions are being made for a mini-Budget and none are likely to be made. On the questions of the effect of changes to the exchange rate on Budget outcomes, I want to stress that the figures I am about to give are very much ball park figures and dependent upon a number of other variables. If the assumptions about any of those other variables are wrong, the outcome figures could be substantially different. But the rule of thumb is that for every one cent reduction in the value of the Australian dollar vis-a-vis the United States dollar, matched by a one-unit movement in the trade weighted index, which is not the same thing as one per cent-it is about 1.4 per cent-outlays would increase by about $50m and receipts would increase by about $100m.

ANSWER.PARA: The principal reason for the increase in receipts-remember that I stipulated a change vis-a-vis the Australian dollar and the United States dollar-is that under the import parity pricing regime for oil a change of one cent in the United States-Australian dollar exchange rate has quite significant revenue implications. It is likely to happen for other reasons also. The major cause of increased outlays with a depreciation of the Australian dollar vis-a-vis the United States dollar is in defence equipment. I have put in a lot of qualifications. The ball park figures are that for one unit movements outlays will increase by about $50m and receipts will increase by about $100m, and therefore the deficit will be reduced by about $50m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CATERING INDUSTRY: INCREASE IN JOB VACANCIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to Commonwealth Employment Service figures that reveal a staggering rise in job vacancies in the New South Wales catering industry and a vast improvement in the South Australian catering industry? How does this equate with the claims made by restaurants and catering associations and some individual restaurateurs that the Federal Government's measures to stamp out tax cheating at the dining table are causing great hardship in that industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the particular figures to which Senator Jones has referred; that is, an increase of 140 per cent in job vacancies in the catering industry in New South Wales. But I have seen reports that CES vacancies notified for restaurants, hotels, clubs and so on for October 1985-which is the most recent month for which we have statistics, for five States and two Territories-show very significant increases in the number of vacancies notified in October 1984. So, far from there being mass retrenchments in the catering industry, as had been predicted by various Jeremiahs opposite, in fact there has been a very big increase in the number of vacancies advertised. In particular, the South Australian vacancies notified increased by 12.3 per cent for October 1985 over October 1984. So the claims of difficulties in obtaining employment in the catering industry are clearly false.

ANSWER.PARA: An article in the Daily Telegraph of 2 December reported Mr Les Rogers, the National President of the Restaurant and Catering Association, as claiming that there would be massive decreases in jobs and so on and massive unemployment in the industry due to the changed taxation treatment; in other words, the sort of hysterical nonsense we listened to for most of the morning. This is flatly contradicted by the CES figures for New South Wales for October 1985, which show that vacancies notified increased from 1,679 in October 1984 to 2,589 in October 1985. That is an increase of just over 54 per cent, which is not quite as high as the figure cited by Senator Jones, but unquestionably it is still a staggering increase in the number of vacancies. Moreover, only three cases of retrenchment could be identified in the 24 regional CES offices in New South Wales-an increase of 900 in the number of job vacancies and only three cases of retrenchment could be identified.

One can draw two conclusions from this: First, that beyond any doubt the claims being made by the Opposition are ludicrous. Secondly-a more general observation-that it is incongruous, to say the least, that a political party which prides itself on adopting some sort of spartan attitude to the economy could believe that one can construct an economy on a foundation of a free lunch.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of a recent report in the Sun-Herald regarding danger to the central nervous system for people who take vitamin B tablets on a daily basis? Is he aware that Professor Truswell, Professor of Human Nutrition at Sydney University, and the Poisons Schedule Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council have expressed alarm at the increasing number of people who are suffering from vitamin inducted peripheral nerve damage, and that both Professor Truswell and the National Health and Medical Research Council have recommended that vitamin B6 in doses greater than 50 milligrams be supplied on prescription only? Given the increasing number of people who seem to believe in the value of taking megadoses of vitamins each day and the many articles which are appearing in newspapers and magazines recommending vitamin B6 in particular for relief from things such as pre- menstrual tension and stress, and given that the tablets are available in health shops and pharmacies in doses as high as 100 times the recommended 2 milligram dose, when will the Government act to limit the availability of megadoses of vitamin B6 to prescription only?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both the Minister for Health and the Government are aware of the increasing numbers of articles which are written in medical journals, and in newspapers for that matter, on the dangers of overdosing with vitamins, and in particular vitamin B6, but also many of the other vitamins which people commonly use. We are also aware that Australian people are amongst the greatest consumers of off the shelf vitamins per capita in the world. That has largely been due to a boom in the keep fit and look after your own health industry in recent years. It has been causing considerable concern to both this Government and previous governments, because not only are we amongst the greatest consumers of vitamins per capita but also we are amongst the greatest consumers of off the shelf medication per se. Vitamin B6 in doses in excess of 50 milligrams can cause central nervous system damage, but so can other vitamins which are taken in excessive doses, such as vitamin A. Vitamin C, if it does not cause direct damage, can certainly interfere with biochemical tests if people are ill.

ANSWER.PARA: The belief that if something is good for people in small doses, it must be much better for them in large doses is a common belief in Australia. There are many people who believe that the same applies to alcohol. Probably the only thing we can really say that about is, I suppose, sex.

I know that in fact Dr Blewett has asked his Department and the National Health and Medical Research Council to look at this matter. I also know that every time anyone at a State or Federal level suggests that there should be some controls over off-the-shelf vitamins, we get flooded with even more mail from the various vested interests than I get over child care. However, in view of the fact that serious reports have been made, I think it is time that the Government took a long hard look at this practice. I will refer the matter again to Dr Blewett who I am sure is looking at it. I will let Senator Haines know whether any details are available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Leader of the Government in the Senate seen the provocative advertisements placed in South Australian newspapers claiming that South Australia's motor car industry is being driven to the wall by the Government? Can the Minister comment on the claims and outline the present situation of the industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It just so happens that not only have I seen the provocative advertisements on this issue in the South Australian newspapers but also I happen to have a copy of one of them with me. I display it to honourable senators opposite so that those of them who are incapably illiterate, if I might put it in those terms, at least will be capable of seeing how big and provocative that advertisement is. Of course, the advertisement is outrageous, misleading and ignorant.
—What does it say?

—It says a number of things. Perhaps the honourable senator can see from where he is sitting that the advertisement says that thousands of workers will join the dole as a result of the fringe benefits tax and its impact on the motor vehicle industry. I would be very surprised if Senator Short was projecting that. Of course, Senator Messner has projected this in the Senate. He has talked in terms very similar to the terms of the advertisement-that is, he has talked in a very misleading and ignorant way. I am not sure who wrote the advertisement but it sounds to me suspiciously like the speech made by Senator Messner. Perhaps it is the same script writer.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make a couple of points. The motor vehicle industry currently is enjoying record sales and record registrations as it has done for the last two years. I believe it has benefited enormously from the Government's policy on the car industry. If one looks at the figures for the last three or four years, one sees that in 1982 there was a miserable increase of 1.7 per cent in total vehicle sales and a mere 0.3 per cent in passenger car sales. In 1984, the first full year of this Government, there was a 12.5 per cent increase in total vehicle sales and an increase of over 10 per cent in passenger car sales compared with the previous year.

The South Australian motor vehicle industry has benefited by that general improvement of the industry as a whole. More importantly, the motor vehicle industry now has the confidence to invest and modernise, as reflected in the activities of a number of major manufacturing companies. For example, the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd has invested $350m on the design and production of a new vehicle for 1988. Mitsubishi, an important South Australian company, has enjoyed singular success with Magna. Mitsubishi has no fears-and this has been articulated by its managing director-about the future of that company in South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good product.
—It is making a good product. That is the important thing.
—Are you talking up Mitsubishi?
—Yes, I am talking up Mitsubishi and I do not retreat from that.
—Ford tomorrow, perhaps.

—No, I am talking up the industry of which Mitsubishi is an important part in South Australia. The honourable senator wants to stir me on this issue. I am sure that any Mitsubishi people who happen to be listening to Question Time today will know that Senator Chaney has accused me of talking up Mitsubishi, as if that had to be done in respect of this very well recognised South Australian company.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point I would like to make relates to the impact of the motor vehicle plan and investment on the component industry. For the first time we are seeing substantial exports from this country from the component sector of the motor vehicle manufacturing industry. There have also been very great improvements in management techniques throughout the industry. Component producers are achieving some success, particularly in export markets-Dunlop with its Pulsar battery and new technology invented and developed in Australia; the Girlock brake company which again operates in South Australia and which exports successfully and ROH of South Australia which is a big exporter of aluminium wheels. All of those components are manufactured by the South Australian vehicle industry. Of course, the largest exporter in the Australian manufacturing sector is General Motors-Holden's Ltd which exports engines to Europe from its Fishermans Bend plant.

I mentioned Mitsubishi in passing but Senator Chaney has provoked me to return to that point. Mitsubishi, of course, has recently announced what I think is a very successful exploration of export markets for its Magna vehicle. These things are important to the industry throughout Australia. They are very important to South Australia which for a long time has been regarded as one of the major centres of the motor vehicle industry. The important point which I seek to make is that the industry is building sound foundations for the future, in terms of technology, marketing skills and so on. These are the important things. The advertisement to which I referred is, as I said, typical of the somewhat ignorant comments which are made about the effects of the fringe benefits tax. I remind honourable senators that any impact on the motor vehicle industry as a result of the fringe benefits tax will be an impact on record production in this country, and that is something which I think has to be recognised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. During the consideration of the Appropriation Bills last week I was assured that I would get an answer to a question I asked before I left this place tomorrow. One of the urgent problems confronting the Tasmanian apple and pear industry is the limited availability of cheap air freight facilities to overseas markets. Is it a fact that overseas owned freight aircraft, which regularly bring goods into Australia, fly out without full loads? Is this practice being pursued in order to protect the interests of Qantas Airways Ltd?

—I have perused Senator Gietzelt's brief and I am afraid that I cannot find the information which Senator Walters requires. However, this is an important matter. I will endeavour to obtain the information before Senator Walters leaves here tomorrow evening-indeed, I hope before all of us leave here tomorrow evening.

—Can the Minister representing the Treasurer say whether the Government believes that the new building approvals figures indicate that the housing industry is operating at satisfactory levels? How do building approvals in South Australia compare with those of recent years? What would be the impact on the housing industry and on home buyers of the Liberal Opposition's policy of deregulating housing interest rates, principally by scrapping the 13 1/2 per cent ceiling on bank home loan interest, compared with the policies of this Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures on building approvals for October, which were released earlier this week, show that in October 1985 some 14,783 approvals were registered compared with 14,031 in the previous October-that is, an increase of around 5 per cent nationally. However, in South Australia, which Senator Maguire mentioned, I think it is even more important to look at the enormous increase in the number of building approvals over the longer term and, in particular, to the quite remarkable improvement that has taken place in the last three years. For example, in the three years from November 1979 to October 1982 some 23,700 approvals in total were issued. In the three years from November 1982 to October 1985 some 38,800 approvals were issued. That represents an increase of 64 per cent for the three years ended October 1985 as against the figure for the three years ended October 1982.

ANSWER.PARA: It is certainly not, of course, coincidental that for the second period when the figure for building approvals was 64 per cent higher, there was a Labor government in South Australia and for the earlier period there was a Liberal government, as indeed there was nationally. So the South Australian economy, along with the economies of the rest of the country, with the possible exception of Queensland, has of course benefited a great deal from the recovery which has taken place over the last three years and the very satisfactory growth rates which have been recorded over the last three years under the joint management of the Bannon Government in South Australia and the Federal Labor Government in Canberra.

That recovery would be placed in jeopardy, however, I regret to say, if a Liberal government should be re-elected and the Liberal Party was given the opportunity to implement its policy of lifting the ceiling on housing interest rates. Indeed, the present Leader of the Liberal Party lifted the ceiling on housing interest rates on three occasions in the last 18 months during which he was Treasurer-by a full 3 per cent, from 10 1/2 per cent as it was prior to 2 December 1980, to 13 1/2 per cent in March 1982. Over that period of less than 18 months the ceiling on housing loan interest rates increased by 3 per cent through three separate increases.

I can only say again to Senator Maguire that it would be a tragedy to South Australia and the nation more generally if this man should ever get the opportunity to implement the sorts of policies he implemented when he was Treasurer, and even more so the sorts of policies which he is now advocating-policies which not even the Government of which he was a member and not even Malcolm Fraser actually advocated or implemented when they were in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the Government's decision to exempt 20 per cent of the value of business goodwill, including farming businesses, when applying the capital gains tax. As a farmer, has the Minister ever heard of any farm being sold with a goodwill component in it? Can the Minister explain this 20 per cent capital gains tax deduction and how it will work in regard to rural properties and farms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several responses, I think, are required to that question. Senator Boswell referred to me as a farmer. That is right, of course. As I told the Senate yesterday, I got more dirt under my fingernails as a farmer than any of the moleskin wearing high-heel boot wearing creatures on the other side of the House ever did.

ANSWER.PARA: As a farmer over the long term, I have not known there to be any real capital gain on the sale of agricultural land. That point is worth making because it demonstrates that the capital gains tax over the long term, if history is any guide, will have absolutely no impact on agriculture, other than possibly to deter foolish people in times of short term speculative booms from paying far too much for agricultural land and getting themselves into a position of a liquidity squeeze, if not outright insolvency, because of that; in other words, doing the sort of thing which a number of farmers, regrettably, did in the early 1980s, particularly sugar cane farmers in Senator Boswell's State of Queensland.

One of the causes of a large number of farmers having liquidity problems today was the absence of a real capital gains tax in the early 1980s. Such an absence encouraged them to get caught up in a speculative boom and to pay far too much for agricultural land, to incur debts which they could not service and which in some cases have induced insolvency today.

The second point is that I do not see how there can be a goodwill component in the sale of a farm, given that agricultural products by and large are marketed anonymously. I could never see that point; I still cannot. That, of course, emphasises again the substantially phoney nature of the campaign that the Liberal Party of Australia was running on the so-called goodwill issue.

In regard to other businesses in which a product or service marketed is not anonymous, as it normally is in relation to agriculture, there will sometimes be a difference between the market-realised price of a business and the salvage value or in situ value of the physical assets of the business. That is referred to as goodwill.

I was not involved in the negotiations between the Treasurer and the Australian Democrats. But Mr Keating, on behalf of the Government, made a concession to the Democrats, as I understand it, in order to secure the passage of the overwhelming majority of the greatest tax reform package which this country has ever seen, which has cemented the accord for another two years, with the economic benefits that flow from it and the tax cuts of which all Australians except the tax cheats will reap the benefits in 1986 and 1987.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister denying on behalf of his Government the deal that the Government and the Australian Democrats worked out between them? Is the Minister saying that there will be no capital gains tax on farms?

—The capital gains tax, with the limited adjustment-a not terribly significant adjustment-which has already been mentioned, will apply to real gains realised on property purchased after 19 September 1985. They are the facts. I am not repudiating the deal that Mr Keating did with the Democrats. My own opinion, if the honourable senator wants it, is that it would be better without that small adjustment. But that was a very small price to pay in order to secure the passage through the Senate of the legislation which, as I said before, comprises the greatest tax reform package which this country has ever seen.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In light of the importance of the report tabled here today on British nuclear testing in Australia and the long term negative consequences of those tests, in view of the fact that the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War have launched a world-wide campaign to persuade the United States to reciprocate the announcement by the Soviet Union of a moratorium on the testing of nuclear weapons until January 1986-since reiterated by Mr Gorbachev's proposal following the Geneva Summit to extend this test ban if the United States follows suit-and in view of the Australian Government's commitment to seeking a comprehensive test ban and our purported special relationship with the United States, will the Government immediately press the United States to support the Soviet initiative?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer that question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for such detailed response as he cares to make. I simply make the point, as was acknowledged in Senator Vallentine's opening salvo, that Australia is very firmly committed to comprehensive test bans by every country in the world, including both the Soviet Union and the United States. We have pressed that point with a great deal of vigour at the Committee on Disarmament meetings and sessions held in Geneva-as Senator Vallentine well knows, as I met her there earlier in the year-and, similarly, in the current session of the United Nations General Assembly.

ANSWER.PARA: The cause has been very vigorously pressed by Australia in that respect-not, regrettably, with much response from either the United States or the Soviet Union. But I assure her, as I am sure the Foreign Minister will when I refer her question to him, that we are doing everything we conceivably can to get that point across.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The particular aspect that I was concerned about was not so much a criticism of the Government's push for a comprehensive test ban treaty, but the specific aspect of the initiative made by Mr Gorbachev which has not been reciprocated by the United States. Can I have an assurance that I will get an answer to that question in this place tomorrow? If the Government is not pressing the United States to support the initiative, I want to know why it is not.
—I will respond to the question in an appropriately constructive spirit. I will see whether I can find Mr Hayden in time to give an answer tomorrow.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. In the union superannuation funds a commission from premiums is paid to union-controlled trustee companies. Can the Minister advise the final destination of those commissions which, for occupational superannuation, would be of the order of $150m a year? Can the Minister assure the Senate that these commissions will not end up in union coffers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know on what basis, if any, that figure of $150m was plucked out. I did hear a question from the Opposition a few days ago in which it was asserted that the total superannuation payment would be in excess of $6 billion, that it would add $6 billion to the national wage bill. Given that, at present gross domestic product, 3 per cent of the total share of wages and salaries paid is of the order of $4.5 billion, and a substantial component of that is in the public sector which would not be affected by the decision made the other day, the $6 billion claim is wildly inaccurate. I do not know whether the $150m to which Senator Parer referred is equally inaccurate, nor do I know whether there is any substance whatsoever to the other details in his question in which he asked about so-called premiums or commissions which would be paid somewhere or other. I will ask Mr Willis whether there is any definitive information to supply on that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: While I am on the subject of superannuation, and related to the question that Senator Parer asked, I did hear on AM this morning, a Mr Brunsdon and Sir Roderick Proctor, who, I understand, is a lackey of the Queensland Premier, making assertions about superannuation. I begin to wonder just what this Government has to do to stop some of these people whingeing. They have been given by this Government the lowest real unit labour costs in more than 15 years, the lowest level of industrial disputation for 17 years, profit share at its highest level for the last 15 years-it is back to the levels of the late 1960s-and still they are whingeing because the prices and incomes accord provided for, subject to a determination of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, some of the productivity increase which has taken place in the last few years to be harvested in the form of superannuation.

When I hear these characters whingeing about these things I wonder whether they would rather have a wage increase, with the on-costs that go with it; alternatively, are they arguing that productivity improvements in perpetuity should accrue entirely to profits, especially given that the level of profits is higher than it has been since the late 1960s-it is back to the late 1960s level? I am not saying that the level is too high, but I am saying that it is a very reasonable proposition-I would be surprised if there are not some people, even honourable senators on the other side of the chamber, who can see this-that some portion of productivity gain should accrue to the work force and some portion, or capital, if you like should accrue to the employer. I think that is an eminently reasonable proposition, and the accord provides for that to happen. I, as a member of a government which has delivered to the business sector more than any government has delivered in the last 15 years, really am sick of this whingeing. We have delivered higher rates of economic growth on a sustained basis than any government has delivered, even in a longer period; the lowest real unit labour costs in 15 years; the lowest level of industrial disputes; and a profit share restored to the level of the late 1960s, which the last tory government never did deliver. I wonder what this Government has to do before Joh Bjelke-Petersen's lackeys will stop whingeing.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BUSINESS: ARTICLE ON FAMILY LAW

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Attorney-General seen the article in Australian Business on 27 November 1985 titled `How to get divorced without getting ruined'? While the article refers to `spouse' and could purport to be non-sexist, the occasional reference to `your wife' indicates that the article is addressed to men, as does the content. In view of the difficulties so many women have in getting maintenance awarded, let alone in having it paid, and in getting adequate, sufficient or fair property settlement, can the Minister comment on this article and say whether he will consider circulating a balanced critique of the article to the Family Court judges?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article, written by a Sydney family law solicitor, which advocates the hiring of family law experts who would use various devices to frustrate the objects of the Family Law Act to prevent fair and equitable financial arrangements for divorcing spouses. The article is quite directly and unashamedly directed to rich businessmen who feel threatened by Family Court property proceedings. Some of the flavour of it can best be conveyed by the following quotations:

ANSWER.PARA: If you arrive in a property division area of the Family Court and all your money stands in your name or in the joint names of your wife and yourself, you have no hope of avoiding the carving that takes place there.
But, if your property has been held judiciously in companies and in trusts, it is possible to avoid not only major surgery but sometimes all surgery.

To put yourself in this situation, you must substitute trustees, accountants and lawyers for your good wife. But, after 20 years or so of marriage and the taking of substantial strides down the path toward being a multimillionaire, they can appear more attractive.
The article goes on a little later to state:
Remember these don'ts:
1. Don't let your spouse be the trustee of the family settlement.
2. Don't let your spouse be the appointor of the family settlement.
3. Don't let your spouse know about the family settlement.
4. Don't make your spouse an equal shareholder in the family company.
5. Don't make your spouse a responsible director in the family company.
6. If your spouse is a shareholder and a director in the family company, then have a holding or an umbrella company in which he or she has no control.

7. Under no circumstances let your spouse acquire a substantial credit loan account in any company operated by you. Always make sure that any credits to loan accounts are spent just as quickly as they are amassed.

That article would be bad enough were it written by some journalist, but it is written, of course, as I said, by someone who purports to be a member of an honourable profession. One would have thought that the person in question would have sheltered under a cloak of anonymity, but not so. His name and his photograph are shown there, as large as life. He is Mr Peter Twigg, of the firm of Adrian Twigg and Co., whose other main claim to fame, of course, is that he was appointed a member of the Government's top family law advisory council-the Family Law Council-for the period 1979-1982, by the then Attorney-General, Senator Peter Durack. So that is the sort of sensitivity there was in the previous Government's appointments relating to the family law subject. I think that is a disgraceful article. I have referred it to the Attorney-General and he has indicated that he is considering taking the matter up with the Acting Chief Judge of the Family Court and the Law Society of New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Special Minister of State and the Attorney-General been drawn to a petition containing 16,000 signatures presented this week to the Prime Minister by Ruth Mackay, daughter of the murdered anti-drug campaigner Donald Mackay, and Dr Richard Smith, Chairman of the Griffith Concerned Citizens Committee? Will the Government proceed to accede to the request contained in the petition that the Griffith drug ring and its national links be given as a reference to the National Crime Authority for attention?

—I have no briefing on this matter. I was not aware of that petition. I will certainly chase it up and find out what is going on. I had understood that those matters were still within the domain of Mr Justice Stewart.
—It is funny how you know so much about a silly article by a man named Twigg but cannot answer a perfectly serious question. Now we know what you read. That is typical.
—I will let that thoroughly, comprehensively wimpish contribution stand on its own terms in Hansard.
—What else do you read at night?

—This is real class! I ask Senator Chaney whether we could have more of these comments in Hansard. I do not know anything about the circumstances of the request that has been made, but I will chase the matter up with the Special Minister of State as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. The Minister would be aware of a front page article by John Spiers in this morning's Australian headed `Age may be factor in 747 collapse'. It related to the collapse of the undercarriage of a Boeing 747 aircraft on landing at Rio de Janiero yesterday. Has the Minister any further information which may help to allay the fears of the travelling public about the safety of such aircraft, especially in the light of the apparent beat-up which this article appears to be?
—I suppose all of us have read the article in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday concerning the Boeing 747 collapse.
—He is a bit out of date.

—Some of us have a bit of trouble catching up. Mr Spiers commented, as Senator McKiernan said, that it is believed age would have been a factor in this case, and referred to other accidents of this type. He said that many aircraft that he would describe as geriatric were flying in the air. Mr Spiers, I think, has done what many journalists and politicians do at various times; he has not let the facts get in the way of a good story. It appears from the Department of Aviation, firstly, that the aircraft concerned was a relatively new one and, secondly, that the undercarriage was down when the aircraft landed, but that the aircraft left the runway and hit a series of obstructions which would have made the undercarriage fail on any aircraft of any age. The accident seems to have little relevance to the claim of broad concern about aircraft safety and structural safety. The Department of Aviation, like other aviation authorities in the world, has no reservations concerning the integrity of the Boeing 747 type and in particular the safety of those aircraft operated by Qantas Airways Ltd. In fact, adequate structural inspection procedures are in place on all Australian airlines' aircraft to cover any concerns about any aging aspects.
—Apart from that, it was a good story.
—The article, apart from all those factual errors, as Senator Baume said, was a good story, dreamt up, I suppose, because Mr Spiers had nothing better to do at the time.

—My question of the Minister representing the Minister for Health relates to the Government's refusal to accede to Commissioner Caesar's request that he be allowed to examine staffing levels in the Australian Capital Territory health system. On what grounds did the Government last night refuse to agree to a review by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of the circumstances-in particular, nurse staffing levels-which gave rise to the present nurses dispute in the Australian Capital Territory? Given that apparently no extra funds will be available in 1985-86, and that hence no extra nurses will be employed, can the Minister provide details of the nature and extent of the reduction in health services to the residents of the Australian Capital Territory in the second half of 1985-86?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has in fact agreed to set up an independent inquiry to deal with the issues arising out of the current industrial dispute involving members of the Royal Australian Nursing Federation and to implement recommendations on the issue of nurses' work loads immediately that inquiry reports. The second term of reference of the inquiry relates to nursing staff resources. The Minister agreed some days ago to place these recommendations before the Government in the context of the development of the 1986-87 Budget. I do not think that he can do otherwise.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday Commissioner Caesar offered to undertake this inquiry if all the parties to the dispute would agree to abide by his recommendations. The Minister for Health sensibly welcomes the involvement of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the area of its jurisdiction. However, Dr Blewett pointed out that, as Commissioner Caesar noted in his statement of 26 November, the jurisdiction of the Commission is with industrial matters. The Minister said that he would not be able to make a commitment for extra resources without first taking such a recommendation to the Government, and that would be possible only within the context of the 1986-87 Budget. The Government has funded the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority to a level that enables it to maintain its services in 1985-86 at the same level as last year. We do not believe that there is any case for an increase in funding beyond that level in this financial year, so that is the reason why Dr Blewett could not make that commitment. No government could make the sort of commitment for which Commissioner Caesar asked. Days before that we had agreed to set up an independent inquiry of the type that Senator Vigor and Commissioner Caesar obviously think is needed.

We certainly wish this ongoing dispute to be settled. The difficulty for nurses at the moment is that more and more nurses are returning to work. My understanding is that yesterday more nurses were at work at the Royal Canberra Hospital than work could be found for. That is the situation of the dispute at the moment. I will seek further information from the Minister if Senator Vigor needs it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. Following the Minister's answer, I would like to know when the Parliament can expect accurate information on the recent reported daily imbalances between nursing needs and nursing staff hours available in the Australian Capital Territory?

—I will seek that information from the Minister for Health, as I said, and provide it for Senator Vigor. We do not want to have a situation where half of the staff of the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority are providing information for answers to Senator Vigor's questions in the way that he apparently thinks other departments can.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications aware of the concern of the people of Parkes at the downgrading of its Telecom office? In view of the social and economic effects of Telecom facilities in rural New South Wales, can the Minister advise of the future of that office?

—After a furious scratch around, I have discovered that I have a note on this. I am advised by Mr Duffy that Telecom Australia does not intend altering the current status of the Parkes Telecom office, which is an outpost of the Dubbo district. Existing staff who directly provide service to the customer will continue to be based in Parkes. However, a small number of clerical positions involved with basic internal administration matters, concerning accounting and personnel functions, will be progressively transferred to Dubbo. These transfers will be made either as a result of a direct request by the staff concerned or as the positions become vacant. So, Emily Renshaw and all the other people of the Parkes telephone exchange have no need to worry.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware that the Canberra Times obtained under the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act, and only after an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, a copy of a report prepared by the Defence Facilities Policy Committee that revealed that the Army does not need the much disputed artillery and infantry centre between Bathurst and Orange, or a manoeuvre area near Cobar? Will the Minister table that report in Parliament? If not, why not? As the report apparently indicates that there is no sound military reason for acquiring this land, will the Government now cancel the Army's land grab in New South Wales and stop harassing my constituents?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator's constituents are sufficiently harassed by having him as their member not to need anything else to add to their burden. I am advised in relation to this matter by the Minister for Defence that papers prepared by the Defence Facilities Policy Committee on Army training area proposals, released yesterday under the Freedom of Information Act, are part of the decision-making process connected with those proposals. The papers have been released in the public interest. I do not imagine, under those circumstances, that there would be any difficulty about tabling them-but I will need to check that with the Minister-so the community at large is aware of the issues which have to be taken into account before final decisions are made on the proposals.

ANSWER.PARA: The views expressed in the papers show that Defence has not treated the proposals lightly or superficially, but has subjected them to searching analysis. The need for the training areas has been examined most comprehensively and final decisions will not be made until all feasible options have been considered thoroughly. Final decisions, I repeat, have not yet been made. The areas of Cobar and Bathurst-Orange had been offered by the New South Wales Government and it had been decided to examine them in detail. However, decisions about them will not be made until military suitability and environmental impact assessments have been completed. These assessments will be brought together in environmental impact statements, which it is hoped will be completed and released for public consideration early in 1986. The types of issues covered in the papers which have just been released will be addressed in the environmental impact statement and it is hoped that release of the papers now will assist the process of public consideration. The Minister for Defence, in his briefing note to me, adds a further rider, which I put on the public record, for what it is worth: `It is hoped too that the information contained in the papers will be treated responsibly by the media'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Do I get the impression from the Minister that the Government was happy to release this information in the public interest? If so, how does that square with the fact that after the Canberra Times sought the release of this information in March under the freedom of information provisions, access was refused by the permanent head of that Department, Sir William Cole, on national security grounds?

—Sir William Cole's views about what is in the public interest may well be different from those of the Minister or other members of his Department. That has been the case in the past, I suspect, and may well be again in the future. The point is that the papers have been released, whatever views might have been formed along the way, and they have been released as a contribution to an informed public debate. I only hope that the honourable senator will respond in the same spirit, and not in his usual churlish and carping fashion, to what is a genuine attempt on behalf of the Minister to inform the public, including Senator Michael Baume-difficult though that task may prove to be.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the Minister advise the Senate on the current status of the Antarctic Treaty following its consideration by the United Nations General Assembly recently? What importance does the Government place on the continued viability of the Treaty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am able to advise the Senate that three resolutions on An- tarctica were adopted in the first Committee of the United Nations General Assembly three days ago on 2 December. They call, among other things, for the United Nations Secretary-General to update his study on Antarctica, and for the Antarctic Treaty consultative parties to report on their negotiations to establish a minerals regime and to exclude South Africa from Antarctic meetings. These resolutions attracted around 80 positive votes on each. About 35 states did not participate in the vote and an equal number absented themselves. With one or two exceptions, parties to the Antarctic Treaty did not participate because of the failure of Malaysia and its friends to adhere to the tradition of consensus in the handling of the Antarctic item.

ANSWER.PARA: The vote was very satisfactory from Austra- lia's point of view. Notwithstanding our objections to elements of the resolutions, the principal resolution did contain formal recognition by the General Assembly of the Antarctic Treaty system, and we regard this as very positive. For the future, we hope that the poor result they obtained will persuade Malaysia and its friends to seek consensus next year. The Antarctic Treaty is important to Australia and we hope that Malaysia, as a close regional friend, would take account of that. It is also important to the world, as a successful instrument for disarmament and peaceful co-operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to his answer to my question without notice on 11 November 1985 concerning any discussion that took place at the recent Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Nassau in respect of the deteriorating human rights situation in Sri Lanka. In the light of the Minister's response that no action was taken by the Australian Government or any other Western government to raise the situation of Sri Lanka at that meeting, I ask: Firstly, what is the present position of the Australian Government's policy in respect of Sri Lanka, and has it altered its policy and procedure in regard to the admission and protection of Tamil refugees? Secondly, why is the Government now advising many Tamils who were granted refugee status in Australia in the years since 1983 to return to Sri Lanka or they will be deported? Thirdly, does the Government consider that it is now safe for them to return to Sri Lanka and, if so, on what grounds was this judgment made?

—Senator Missen has pursued this matter at Question Time on previous occasions. I can indicate, of course, that the Government remains concerned about the communal problems in Sri Lanka and particularly the violence and human suffering which has accompanied those disturbances. It believes that an early political solution to the problem is essential and it hopes that direct political dialogue over the problems can soon be resumed. Following the disturbances, arrangements were made to expedite consideration of Sri Lankan migrant entry cases to Australia and to approve for entry under the special humanitarian program those who were adversely affected by the disturbances-mainly Tamil people. More than 730 persons have been given special visas under the special humanitarian program. In addition, temporary entrants to Australia who had fears about returning to Sri Lanka have been permitted to extend their entry permits and they will not be threatened with deportation. The Government is constantly monitoring the situation and the arrangements under the two programs I have mentioned will remain in force as long as they are required.

—On 2 December Senator Townley asked Senator Gietzelt a question without notice concerning the nationality of the person who selects pilots chosen to fly for Qantas and whether some Qantas pilots are in fact foreign pilots. The answer I have been given is as follows: Qantas pilot selection is, in fact, not made by one person. There are nine separate selection steps involved in the procedure and no single member of Qantas's staff is involved in all of the steps. The present Qantas pilot selection policy requires an applicant, inter alia, to hold Australian permanent residence status and Australian pilot licences.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kilgariff asked me a question a couple of days ago about an article in the Bulletin relating to nuclear testing in the Pacific to which I promised to give him an answer as soon as possible. I am now able to do that, courtesy of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in the following terms: The honourable senator's question addresses two separate issues. Firstly, the Government's particular condemnation of French nuclear testing arises from the fact that France conducts its tests in the South Pacific region--
—If it is a long answer, why don't you incorporate it?
—I am happy to incorporate it. I am just observing the spirit and conventions of this place. Mr Deputy President, I ask leave for the answer to be incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
TESTING IN THE PACIFIC
The Honourable Senator's question addresses two separate issues.

2. The Government's particular condemnation of French nuclear testing arises from the fact that France conducts its tests in the South Pacific region contrary to the expressed wish of the people of the region. More broadly, there is the Government's long-standing concern to see the conclusion of a Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty which would bring about an end to all testing by all countries in all environments for all time. It places the highest priority on the conclusion of such an agreement.

3. As to missile tests, the United States, the Soviet Union and China all test nuclear capable ballistic missiles to impact points in the Pacific. The Government understands that since 1975 all Soviet tests into the Pacific have been to impact areas in the North Pacific. The United States also has a Pacific missile test range, with an impact area near Kwajalein Atoll in the North Pacific. The Government has not protested to either country regarding its missile tests in the North Pacific and has no plans to do so. The testing of delivery vehicles is, of course, an entirely different thing from test explosions, not least in terms of possible environmental consequences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer briefly to the fact that on 2 December, during the debate on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985, while Senator Peter Baume was speaking I interjected in relation to the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and said:

SPEECH.PARA: It does not pay proper rates or proper rent.
I emphasise the word `proper'. Later in that debate on 3 December Senator Grimes said:
Senator Peter Rae, by interjection last night, extended that argument. He said that CSL had such an advantage in that it did not have to pay rents and rates. That is quite false.
Senator Walters said:
He didn't say that.
Senator Grimes then said:

Senator Peter Rae did say that last night by interjection, but it is quite false. In fact, CSL does pay rent to the Commonwealth and it pays rates to the Woodend Council in Melbourne of about $760,000 per annum.

Senator Grimes talked about people having knee-jerk responses, and a little later he gave some further information which elaborated on what he had already said about the $760,000. I simply wish to point out that in 1980 the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations investigated CSL and its financial statements and in a report, which is Parliamentary Paper No. 59/1980, the Committee reported:

CSL's main buildings are situated at Parkville in Melbourne on about 33 acres of land owned by the Commonwealth. This land is in fact the most important of the assets in the custody of CSL which were referred to earlier. Because CSL does not own the land, its value is not included in the `Fixed Assets' listed in CSL's balance sheet for 1978-79.
I might say also that it is not listed in CSL's balance sheet for 1983-84, which is the most recent one available. The report further stated:
The Committee notes that this fact alone lessens the comparability of CSL's balance sheet with that of any similar public listed company.
It went on:
CSL informed the Committee that rent is in fact paid to the Commonwealth for the land, although no formal lease agreement has ever existed.
The report continues:
The rent . . . was believed to include some amount in respect of rates, although the Commonwealth does not pay rates to the Municipal Authority.

The land on which CSL pays this amount of rent is prime Melbourne inner city real estate. While an accurate assessment of its commercial value is not available and may present some difficulty due to uncertainty in relation to its alternative uses and future zoning, there can be no doubt that the amount paid by CSL is far less than the economic rent. CSL stated in evidence that because part of the land was used for `national interest' purposes, it assumed that the rent was calculated for only that part used for commerical purposes.

The situation is obviously both informal and unclear. The Committee is concerned that this arrangement means that CSL's financial statements do not fully reflect either its available resources or the extent of the taxpayers subvention to its activities, because the true value of the land which it uses is not shown. To this extent CSL's statements do not disclose as much as those of a comparable public company. Commercial comparability is not available.

The report went on to talk about rates and indicated that the fact that no full rating contribution was made also gave CSL an advantage which was not enjoyed by its competitors and made its performance lacking in comparability. I add, in case Senator Grimes thinks that there is something different in the most recent report, that I am sure that everybody would be delighted to have the most recent report tabled. I understand from CSL that it has been sent into the bureacuracy, but it has not emerged from there. It is now five months since the end of the financial year for which the report was due and CSL is therefore out of time in presenting its report. If that report provides information which shows that I am wrong, obviously it is the fault of CSL and the Government in not getting that information out in time which has caused any error. I believe that there is unlikely to be any error as I understand that the rental expense was only $708,000 in 1984-85. The figure may have gone up this year to $877,000, but it is still an extremely low amount to pay for the very valuable land and buildings which are occupied and used by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. I believe that the land to which Senator Grimes referred is land of relatively low value which is owned by CSL and which is in a different area entirely and is not the extremely valuable 33 acres of land on the outskirts of the city of Melbourne. In other words, I believe that what I said was accurate and I object to being called a liar in relation to it.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce has an important role in advising and implementing government policy in relation to Australian manufacturing and service industries and technology and it is a focal point of interaction between business, unions and Federal and State governments. I draw the Senate's attention to a significant paragraph of the report, and that is the one which states that the Australian economy has grown up around a framework of government intervention in industries and the key question for government is how to modify the framework of intervention so as to improve the ability of the economy to achieve the required structural change. The plight of manufacturing industry must continue to exercise some concern for both the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and his Department. Over the past 15 years we have seen the loss of 150,000 jobs. Of those 150,000 jobs, 140,000 were actually lost during the Whitlam years.

Our inability to compete internationally and the failure of our industries to exploit modern technology and opportunities for growth, particularly in the Pacific region, have caused us problems. Those problems have been manifested very much in the form of a relative decline in our standard of living. For example, 40 years ago Australia ranked fourth amongst the most prosperous nations in the world, whereas today Australia is ranked seventeenth. I think that we were all very much relieved in Australia when the current Australian Labor Party Government showed that it had a much more responsible attitude to the preservation of the manufacturing sector in Australia. I think it is true that the manufacturing sector must be rejuvenated. It needs government co-operation to recover from the slump. At the same time, government needs to ensure that its relative policies in manufacturing interact properly with its tax policies so that good work done in, say, the manufacturing area is not dissipated by ideological beliefs imposed through taxation measures which react against manufacturing industry.

However, I believe that on all sides there is now a very much wider recognition of the need to preserve our manufacturing industries in Australia. I think that we have passed the time when many of our academics suggested that we should abandon our current manufacturing industries in favour of high technology industries. I think that this has been dispelled by the realisation that the costs, both economic and social, in terms of dislocation could never be recouped. Last year Australian industry was so uncompetitive internationally that our firms supplied only $1m of the $200m worth of products which were ordered world-wide by the United Nations Children's Fund. Many of our manufacturers are reluctant to tender in the international field.

I think the question that needs to be asked is: Why do Australian manufacturers and service industries not take more advantage of the opportunities around us? Firstly, we have to recognise that many of these industries, particularly in South East Asia in future will suffer tax consequences as a result of the new tax reform measures. Also, many of those industries face tremendous competition from other international suppliers who receive tremendous levels of assistance and subsidies from their own respective governments. There is also the problem of our own industrial disputations and stoppages. It is felt that Australia is not always a reliable supplier as far as the rest of the world is concerned.

Many of our industries are faced with high labour and transport costs which undermine our international competitiveness. There is also labour market rigidity, which is a barrier to the development of more efficient and export-related industries. Many of the wage fixing practices are an incredible obstacle to effective overseas competition and also the domestic rationalisation of our industries. Thus it is almost impossible to institute any form of structural change in response to international demand. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority is quite significant. I automatically tie the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority in with the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, because I think that they are both synonymous and work together in very important respects. The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation has adopted a very important role internationally with respect to assisting other countries technologically with respect to engineering works. It seems to me that the importance of these two authorities escapes the notice of government. I refer particularly to the problem of water resource development in Australia. The Authority did make a false start when it used the New South Wales Public Works Department to construct an early dam with consequent overruns of cost and time. Thereafter it concentrated on investigation and design and it used the private sector to construct the remainder of the works with consequent world records being set for dam and tunnel construction. Contracts were completed on time and final costs were less than those estimated.

The Snowy Mountains Authority is an excellent example of how to use the private sector and to develop a mix of public and private enterprise. Strangely this type of management was introduced in South Australia by the Tonkin Liberal Government which was able, through attrition, to reduce the number of public employees by 4,500 thereby saving the taxpayers of South Australia of the order of $60m a year. It is the policy that the John Olsen government is determined to follow after Saturday when it will be elected to govern that State.

The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation and the Hydro-electric Authority have earned a reputation throughout the world for engineering and design expertise. They have supervised construction in collaboration with great engineering contractors in Australia and overseas. We ought to be utilising their expertise in a much more effective way in Australia. I have always said that one of our priceless resources happens to be water. I have a great regard for instrumentalities such as the River Murray Commission. It is my concern that we need to address ourselves to the establishment of a national water authority which ought to incorporate the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation and the River Murray Commission in order to come to grips with the fact that by the year 2000 in the northern Spencer Gulf area of South Australia, for example, the demand for water will exceed supply.

I am sure Senator Grimes would appreciate the fact that we cannot do anything about the development of Australian enterprise, mining, agriculture or cope with the increase in population looking forward to the year 2000 and beyond, unless we do something about a national water resources policy. An ideal way to come to grips with that is to utilise the expertise available in the River Murray Commission with respect to advisory matters, the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority, which is recognised world wide as an engineering organisation and SMEC and come to grips with the problems that will face Australia beyond the year 2000.

I commend the report to the Senate. It is about time we recognised that uranium is not our most important resource; coal is not our most important resource. Water happens to be the most vital resource for Australia's continued development beyond the year 2000.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Public Service Board 1984-85 annual report is a most important report. It details the circumstances of the Commonwealth Public Service as at 31 December 1984. This year a special chapter is devoted to `Youth Employment in the Australian Public Service-A Statistical Profile'. I am pleased that the Commonwealth Public Service Board, after many statements by me in this chamber, has at least spent a considerable amount of time dealing with, if not justifying, the lamentable situation of youth employment in the Public Service.

The figures speak for themselves. The annual report of the Public Service Board which has been tabled today reveals that youth employment in the Public Service has sunk to an all time low and `without explicit policy intervention it will decline further over the next five years'. That is a tragedy; it is quite extraordinary particularly in view of the full page advertisements that are currently being splashed around the nation asking youth to ring the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to tell him what ought to be done. I will tell him; I do not have to ring him. I am not a youth anyhow. He should get his Ministers to give youth a fair share of employment opportunities in their departments. The position, as revealed by this document, shows that in 1966 youth comprised some 22.2 per cent of permanent Public Service staff. This figure declined to 6.3 per cent in 1984 and the projected figure for 1985 is 5.5 per cent-the very year which is supposed to be International Youth Year, the very year in which the Government proposed that youth be priority one.

I notice photographs of the Minister for Finance and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, Senator Walsh, and the Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, at the beginning of the report. Those Ministers have a specific task and ought to develop explicit policy intervention measures to ensure that youth has its fair share of jobs. Of course they will say that the Commonwealth intends to introduce youth traineeships. These have been categorised by some Public Service unions as attempts to supplant full time, permanent jobs with temporary traineeships. The argument presumably put by the Government is that traineeships will give youth a better chance to be appointed to the permanent Public Service staff. Who is youth competing with? Our young people are competing with experienced adults and if they are not given a fair go and a fair share of appointment opportunities they will always miss the boat. Page 118 of the report states:

The most significant points to emerge from Figure 4 are the very substantial and steady decline in appointments of persons aged less than 21 years-in this age group representation of men among total new appointments fell from 29.8 per cent to 9.5 per cent, while women's representation fell from 34.1 per cent to 20.5 per cent---

Clearly this tragic state of affairs for youth has been brought about by deliberate policy decisions which still remain in force denying jobs particularly to young girls who want to join the Public Service. It is a tragedy which needs rectification and urgent attention.
