It is clear that what is likely to happen is that Qantas and other airlines will carry more duty free liquor on board in order to sell it to their passengers. If Senator Sanders is concerned about that matter, he ought to take that consideration into account. Senator Sanders said that people will buy their duty free goods in Australia. I suppose he does not give a hoot about the fact that the principal concessionaire at Sydney Airport is a non-Australian company which repatriates home most of its profits. It got the contract for the duty free shop at Sydney Airport by putting in what was undoubtedly a loss leading tender. It undercut other companies. It undercut Australian companies in order to get this contract. The contract was so bodgie that the company had to come back to the Government, once it had been given this monopoly contract, to renegotiate it. At page 1866 of the Senate Hansard of 13 May 1985 honourable senators will see an answer provided by Senator Gietzelt, representing the Minister for Aviation, to my question about why the contract had to be renegotiated. I asked: What were the terms of the new contract? The terms are set out in the Hansard. The contract had to be renegotiated.

On 15 May I put on notice question No. 302 asking: How many other contracts have had to be renegotiated because they were so bad? To this day, that question remains unanswered on the Notice Paper. That is an indication of the sorts of people who Senator Sanders says ought to have this material made available to them. The concessionaire at Melbourne Airport has been criticised in the September 1984 report of the Auditor-General upon audits, examinations and inspections under the Audit and other Acts. This report is parliamentary paper No. 170 of that year. At page 112, under the heading `Location of Duty Free Premises at Melbourne International Airport', the Auditor-General criticises a lack of security at those premises.

I turn to the question which the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, raised about barrier control and the problems that raises. The first and most important thing to say is that one has to look in the first instance to the fact that this will be a revenue losing operation. The details of that revenue loss are contained in the submission by the Australian Taxation Office to the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry on passenger concessions. Page 31 of the submission summarises its position-I do not have time to go into it now-which demonstrates clearly that inward duty free will be a loss to the Australian revenue.

The Australian Democrats have been telling us for the last couple of weeks in respect of the tax package how much they are in favour of small business. The Australian Small Business Association, in its submission to the Industries Assistance Commission, said specifically that inward duty free shopping should not be introduced. It said that it would be deleterious to small business, that it extended the concept too far and could not be supported by it. On 6 May 1985 it put out a Press release headed `Small Business Condemns Inward Duty Free Decision'. Therefore, we come to the questions of security. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a submission made to the IAC in April 1985 by the Australian Customs Service.
Leave granted.
The submission read as follows-
INDUSTRIES ASSISTANCE COMMISSION INQUIRY INTO PASSENGER AND CREW CONCESSIONS
SUBMISSION BY
THE AUSTRALIAN CUSTOMS SERVICE
PASSENGER AND CREW PROCESSING AND FACILITATION

As the authority responsible for the adminstration of the passenger concessions, it is not our role to comment on questions of fiscal policy (e.g. revenue foregone) or on matters not directly related to ACS operations (e.g. financing of airports, the effect on Australian industry or the efficiency of national resource allocation). The prime area of concern for the ACS in respect of passenger concessions is the facilitation of passengers and the allocation of resources to that function. The resource question involves Government consideration of the priorities it needs to apply in the allocation of resources to Government Administration, particularly in times of restraint, and ACS consideration of how it in turn should deploy resources to meet the Government's priorities.
Philosophy

Passenger concessions exist for two reasons. Firstly, to facilitate the inward movement of passengers and, second, to release passengers from duty liability on articles commonly carried as personal possessions and necessities purchased for the journey. There can be, of course, subsidiary reasons for the concessions; for example, they have been held to be a means of assisting migrants to overcome problems in bringing assets with them into Australia, and Australia grants concessions contained in international Conventions to which Australia is a signatory.

The facilitation philosophy finds international acceptance in Annex F.3 to the Customs Co-operation Council Convention on The Simplification and Harmonization of Customs Procedures (the ``Kyoto'' Convention). Australia is a signatory to the Kyoto Convention, has acceded to a number of its Annexes and is at an advanced stage in the process of adopting Annex F.3.

The Customs view is that concessions should be realistic. That is, they should recognise that people will make purchases and should avoid the need for collection of duty on reasonable purchases of the nature contemplated by the concessions. The latter should be structured in such a way that they can be interpreted easily and that travellers who know they must pay duty will do so voluntarily. The concessional regime should not provide an incentive for travellers to seek to evade duty. Equally, of course, general concessions, say on sales tax, can be overly generous and raise questions of equity in relation to the majority of the population.

The Customs concern is to steer a line which will not create an atmosphere of policing and not encourage petty smuggling. It has to be said that, apart from resource questions, there is a matter of priorities involved. Relatively minor duty evasions cannot rate highly as compared with narcotics or quarantine breaches. At the same time, Customs deprecates the attitude of some regular travellers who move in what might be termed the ``loot'' area of concessions, that is, high value items not usually thought of as affordable by the average citizen. In that context, it should be noted that Australia's concessions are generous by international standards. The concessions are not, and should not be regarded as, a grant. Moreover, they are not linked in any way to the ``free port'' philosophy (which has sway, for example, in Hong Kong, Singapore and Fiji), which is much broader in concept and is based on quite different considerations, in that it is designed to encourage i.e. industrial development, investment, retail opportunities and commercial export incentive programs, and to bring in revenue.
Administration
An essential element for facilitating the entry of passengers by providing concessional treatment to goods carried by them is simplicity of administration.

One aspect is that the concessions available should be sufficient to permit a relatively unimpeded flow through the Customs barrier for the majority of passengers, by keeping to a minimum the incidence of duty collection. If it were necessary (because of the non-existence of reasonable concessions) to collect duty from the majority of passengers, or to examine significantly more baggage to prevent smuggling, the increase in ACS staff resources needed to ensure that processing delays did not occur would be considerable. In the absence of allocation of additional resources in the Budget, which may not be possible, this would result in deployment of staff from another area of operations with inevitable consequences to it.

Another aspect is that concessions should be able to be interpreted and applied without real difficulty, both by the passenger and the ACS. Difficulties in interpretation and application cause delay at the Customs Barrier. A factor in this is that exceptions to the rule should be kept to a minimum. Examples are concessions accorded serving crews (limited to once a year), migrants, tourists of different nationalities and constant travellers (e.g. couriers who may pass through the Customs barrier every 10 days). As a further example the existing concessions allow `Articles for personal hygiene, grooming or adornment'. An exception to this concession for, say, `items of jewellery, purchased overseas and exceeding $100 each in value' could cause considerable administrative difficulties for the ACS and could involve, for example:
the registration of items of jewellery taken out of Australia by passengers and verification at time of re-importation;
the registration of jewellery temporarily imported by tourists and verification on re-exportation;
the valuation of all items of jewellery by the ACS-this would mean recruitment of a significant number of specialist staff; and
an increase in the number of passengers from whom duty would be collected.

All of the above would lead to additional delays in passenger processing (unless resources devoted to it were considerably increased) and negate the objective of facilitation. The above example is given as indicative of the type of administrative considerations that can arise. Changes introduced in the last ten years have sought to simplify the administration of the concessions available to passengers, afford reasonable facilitation for imports by passengers and minimise delays in processing times to ensure that airport facilities (in particular) do not become overloaded.
The Effects of Changes in Concessions/Administration
It may be worthwhile to illustrate the facilitation question by taking a specific element of the Commission's reference, that is, inwards duty free shopping (IDFS).

Shopping by inward passengers could well aggravate queueing at major airports if subsequent flights arrive while passengers from earlier flights are still proceeding to the primary line. This would result in problems both for processing passengers at the primary line, and for congestion (from the carousels) in the Customs Hall, even to the extent of causing later baggage to be held in the basement awaiting space.

There may be a tendency for passengers to confuse the extent of the concessions and overspend their allowance, thereby increasing congestion at the primary line as Customs would have to collect additional duty.

Last minute shopping could cause amendments to baggage statements to be necessary on occasions, according to purchases, and the primary desk is not the place where passengers should complete/amend the statement.

There is the further problem of completion of statements (in aircraft en route) where it is not then certain what will finally be in the baggage. Alterations could make for evidentiary difficulties later.

Surveys conducted by the ACS indicate that if IDFS were available there would be an upward trend in both the number of passengers who purchase duty free goods and the value of those goods. This would have two effects in particular:
(i) an increase in the revenue foregone; and
(ii) an increase in processing time for each passenger, with a consequent increase in staff resources needed if delays were to be minimized.

An additional problem is that IDFS staff would be located within the Customs area leading to an added risk of narcotics and message exchange. This would require additional Customs surveillance workload and increased manpower. The security screen would have to extend to checking IDFS staff each time they left the premises (e.g. lunch, visits to toilets, leaving work for the day). Monitoring would be required of deliveries to and from the IDFS and rubbish removal. There would be a requirement of police/character checks on IDFS staff.
The above comments illustrate the implications which concessions and their administration can have:
at the primary line, where the determination is made whether duty is payable;
at the baggage channel, where the extent of concessions used is verified; and
within duty free premises themselves, to ensure that the barrier is not being breached by shop personnel or others connected with duty free operations.
Delays at the first point in the Customs clearance chain lead to an increased number of representations criticising inadequate facilitation.

In a circumstance of resource pressures resulting from a particular concessions regime, there is some risk that the increased emphasis on verifying passenger concessions usage could be detrimental to Customs effectiveness in the high priority areas of narcotics, quarantine and community protection.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. That submission makes it abundantly clear that the Customs Service is concerned about security and smuggling issues. Because the submission is now in the Hansard, I will not read it. However, I draw attention to two other reports which relate to this. The first is the report of the Mahony Review of Customs Administration and Procedures (in New South Wales). That report specifically drew attention to the problems of security if inward duty free shopping were introduced. The reference can be found at pages 121 and 122 of the report. Today we received the annual report of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. At pages 92 and 93 of the annual report which was presented to this Parliament only today, the Mahony report is raised specifically. The report says in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The single major influence of the year under review was the Government's development of a national campaign against drug abuse.
The report continues:

. . . The Mahony report on the Review of Customs Administration and Procedures in New South Wales had recommended a tightening of barrier controls and this recommendation was also accepted by the Government as part of its national campaign.

That tightening of barrier controls will be undermined by the introduction of inward duty free shopping. Arising from this will be the major problem of airport congestion at the terminals. The Daily Telegraph of 17 May 1985 reported that the Federal Government had been told that the international passenger terminal at Sydney Airport had become `alarmingly' congested. That complaint was made by international airlines. A comment was made in the IAC's draft report on passenger concessions. It is stated on pages 87 and 88 of the report:

There seems little doubt that an inward duty free store would increase the security problems substantially. The Commission understands that authorities in the United States of America strongly oppose inward duty free shopping on security grounds.
Again, because of lack of time, I will not go through all that the Commission had to say, but further on it states:
If the export objective of duty free shopping is abandoned in favour of maximising passengers' utilisation of import concessions, there would be little to criticise in such a proposal.
But that is not the proposal that the Government has come forward with. Its conclusion is:
The Commission does not believe that inward duty free shopping helps to achieve any of these objectives--
those being passenger facilitation, immigration, cost effectiveness, and Customs administration-

Indeed, the probability is that it would hinder Customs in processing passengers and achieving other objectives of barrier control. The Commission does not therefore consider that passenger import concessions should apply to goods purchased in Australia by arriving persons before they pass through the Customs barrier.

Senator Sanders is the great expert on barrier control and Customs administration. He has told the Senate that, despite the lengthy hearings by the Industries Assistance Commission which says that inward duty free shopping will hamper its barrier operations, despite the submission by the Customs Service that it will hamper its barrier operations, he knows better. We have the whole sorry tale of the way in which this was introduced. The first report of the Bureau of Transport Economics was presented in September 1979. That report was sent to an interdepartmental committee which rejected its findings. Another interdepartmental committee was set up. That committee was under the chairmanship of Senator Button's Department. For various reasons, it passed from that Department's chairmanship. His Department has been consistently opposed to inward duty free shopping. His Department surrendered the chairmanship to Mr John Brown's Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism.

That Department sought to mislead the Senate and the Parliament in last year's annual report by the way in which it made its report on inward duty free shopping. I challenged the Department on that. The Senate Hansard of Estimates Committee D of 18 April 1985 shows that I challenged the Department on that and the Department had to make all sorts of excusses and retreats. Again, funnily enough, the report which has come in only today-the 1984-85 annual report of the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism-apologises in effect, at pages 92 and 93, for having misled people in last year's annual report; that is, the 1983-84 annual report. Page 110 of that report referred to inward duty free shopping. In answer to a Senate question it was indicated on 8 May that the interdepartmental committee report referred to at that time related to departmental inputs to the preparation of a Cabinet submission on inward duty free shopping. So the Department has been forced to back down on the way in which it has attempted to cover up in this whole operation.

I do not have the time to explore all of the other matters which are of significance here-for instance, the submissions by the Fiji High Commission, the Fiji Visitors' Bureau and the Fiji National Duty Free Merchants Association to the IAC asking it not to proceed because of the damage that inward duty free would do to its small regional economies, and the submission by the Department of Foreign Affairs asking the IAC not to proceed. Finally I came back to drugs. I refer again to one of the comments in the IAC report which states:
Incoming passengers could pass contraband to arrival shop staff who would later bring it through the barrier.

On 27 November 1985, in the debate in the House of Representatives on page 3835 of Hansard Mr Fife, the honourable member for Hume and a former distinguished and respected Minister for Customs, who consistently rejected appeals for the introduction of inward duty free shopping because of the advice of his Customs advisers, stated that the Government was `running a risk that no responsible government should ever take'.

The motion which has been moved by Senator Chaney, and which is fully supported by the Opposition, is a simple one. It acknowledges that there are arguments about the security provisions for control of inward duty free shopping. There are arguments that touch upon the fundamental question of whether a threat is posed to young people in Australia and to the Australian community in general, by the importation of drugs. That threat exists and has been identified by the Australian Customs Service, interdepartmental committees, the Mahoney review and in numerous submissions to the IAC and has been identified and rejected by previous Ministers for Customs because it posed too serious a challenge for it to be allowed to go ahead without further examination. On that basis further examination by a Senate committee is entirely justified and Senator Chaney's motion ought, for that reason alone, be supported. Those who fail to support it and fail to see the strength of that argument are determined to put political or commercial interests ahead of the fundamental interest of the security of young people and the whole Australian community in the vital war which we have to fight against organised crime and the drug trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to this debate. As has been pointed out, there have been all sorts of views about the issue of inward duty free shopping, some of them informed, some of them less informed, some of them not informed at all and indeed some quite ignorant. Some of those views are highly speculative, and it is very difficult to draw conclusions about them. I understand some of the concerns which have been expressed by the Opposition. I have a great deal of confidence in the Australian Customs Service and the capacity of its officers. That is a very sustaining thought for the Minister responsible for Customs.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to all the views that have been expressed. Some of those expressed in the House of Representations were colourful. I particularly noted the contribution of Mr Ian Cameron, the honourable member for Maranoa and a member of the Opposition, in respect of inward duty free shopping. He stated:

Unfortunately, the National Party of Australia is having its Christmas party tonight. I have not drunk too much rum but I have had a couple of whiskies. I am a bit more worldly than Government members. One of the problems I have is that my side of the House is opposing this idea, but I think it is a damn good idea so that puts me in a quandary. As one who travels a bit and drags stuff in and out of the country I think the present arrangement for duty free goods is absurd.
He continued that if the Government is fair dinkum-they are my words:

. . . why does it not include all products sold at airports-electrical goods, cameras et cetera? I do not know why the Government restricts this to only a few products. I do not doubt that as time goes by we will expand this principle to other areas.

There is the authentic view of the National Party of Australia at work in the House of Representatives. As Senator Puplick acknowledged when defending his probity and integrity on this matter, he is not without a course record of various views on some of these issues. I do not allege anything in respect of that. I think he has changed his mind from time to time. Certainly he has changed his mind if the vehemence of his contribution to this debate is indicative of his present state of mind. However, that is bound to happen.

The Government has made a decision in respect of inward duty free shopping. I indicated in a letter to Senator Chipp-it was read by Senator Sanders; it is very gratifying to note that they read my letters-that this measure would be confined to the three items in question. It will be. In those circumstances I rely very much on the arguments which were put at some length in the House of Representatives.

Earlier in the debate on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) Senator Chaney raised the issue of duty rates for machine tool parts and accessories. I do not want to dwell at length on that issue but I think I should just explain the background. In 1983 a simplification of the tariff led to a drop in the rate of duty from 26 per cent to 2 per cent for metal working machine tool parts and accessories. As a result local producers made submissions to the Industries Assistance Commission and gave evidence to it of some substantial drop in sales and production as a result of that reduction in duty. The IAC, in its 1984 report on metal working machine tools, recommended that parts and accessories for use as original equipment in the production of machine tools be bountiable and dutiable at minimum rates. It also recommended that other parts and accessories for replacement purposes be dutiable at 25 per cent. In other words the IAC restored the situation to what it was prior to 1983. The Government accepted these recommendations on assistance for parts and accessories and rejected the possibility of bounties for parts and accessories because the cost would have been too great.

The IAC noted in its report that many parts and accessories are not manufactured locally. In that circumstance which is the point of the tariff concession system, importers should be able to apply for tariff concession orders which, if they are granted-they would be in circumstances where there is no local manufacturer-would allow imports to be made at the 2 per cent rate rather than the 25 per cent rate. That is the essence of what Senator Chaney was seeking to have put on the record. A number of matters have been raised in the debate but I do not wish to deal with anything other than the substance of what honourable senators have said. I commend the legislation to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

Clauses 4, 6, 7, 12, 17 and 18 of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985, and clause 13 and Schedule 8 of the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition proposes to oppose clauses 4, 6, 7, 12, 17 and 18 and to vote against those clauses in the Customs Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), and to vote against clause 13 and schedule 8 of the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985. The reason for that is that all of those clauses and that schedule relate to the Government's proposal to institute inward duty-free shopping. I do not wish, at the Committee stage, to go back over all the ground that has been canvassed in the second reading debate but I should like to touch on some of the matters which have already been raised.

SPEECH.PARA: I was particularly pleased to hear the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, in his defence of what is proposed, express his confidence in the Australian Customs Service. I do not in any way demur from that expression of confidence or disagree with it, but I draw the Minister's attention, the Senate's attention-that of the Australian Democrats in particular-to the views of the Australian Customs Service in which the Minister has so much confidence. The Customs Service made a submission to the Industries Assistance Commission. That submission is a public document. I should like to advise the Committee of one of the views expressed by the Customs Service with respect to this matter. I quote from the submission:

An additional problem is that inward duty-free shopping staff would be located within the Customs area leading to an added risk of narcotics and message exchange. This would require additional customs surveillance workload and increased manpower. The security screen would have to extend to checking inward duty-free shopping staff each time they left the premises (for example, lunch, visits to toilets, leaving work for the day). Monitoring would be required of deliveries to and from the inward duty-free shopping and rubbish removal. There would be a requirement of police/character checks on inward duty-free shopping staff.
Later in the same submission, the Customs Service said:

In the circumstances of resource pressures resulting from a particular concession regime, there is some risk that the increased emphasis on veryifying passenger concessions usage could be detrimental to Customs effectiveness in the high priority areas of narcotics, quarantine and community protection.

I do not seek to overemphasise or in any way to misrepresent the views that are put forward by Customs. They refer to `some risk'; they refer to the fact that it `could be detrimental to Customs effectiveness in the high priority areas of narcotics, quarantine and community protection'. That is a view which seems to be reflected and has been accepted as a consideration worthy of being put forward by the Industries Assistance Commission. The simple point which the Opposition makes is that we do not believe that in circumstances of doubt we should simply pass these provisions and hope for the best.

I am totally unimpressed, and indeed I am somewhat taken aback, by the attitude which was evidenced by the speaker for the Australian Democrats. His rather contemptuous pushing off of the views which I put forward, on the basis that this was an aviation matter and not a Customs matter, I find very hard to understand. Frankly, I think that the obviously quite marginal advantages which accrue or may accrue to aviation if this change is made just do not weigh very heavily in the balance when held up against the possibility that there will be further weakening of barrier controls against the possible introduction of narcotics and other matters. So I express considerable surprise that the usually would-be idealist Australian Democrats should take the stance that was put forward by Senator Sanders, and I would express the hope that it does not represent the view of his Democrat colleagues.

Again, I do not wish to flog the horse; I hope it is not a dead horse. I hope that honourable senators are alive to the arguments which have been put forward and will see it as a desirable matter that there should be careful consideration of the barrier control aspects of this legislation.

I do not wish to expend much time on the other many arguments which are available as to the advantages and disadvantages, but perhaps I may quote from one other submission to the Industries Assistance Commission, that put in by the Department of the Treasury. In its penultimate paragraph, its says:

The extension of taxation concessions is not considered an appropriate response to passenger in-flight behavioural problems or rising airline fuel costs. In regard to fuel savings, the argument is simply ludicrous when the value of fuel savings is set against the amount of Commonwealth revenue foregone. Further, the reduction in Commonwealth revenue collections must outweigh any increase in on-airport duty-free licence revenue. In any event, extra licence free revenue collected by the Department of Aviation would primarily benefit international airline operators and international air travellers by allowing airline rentals and airfares to be lower than otherwise. In effect, ordinary taxpayers would be subsidising overseas travel.

I just wonder at the priorities of the government and at the priorities of the Australian Democrats. I commend to the Committee the proposition that we should vote against those clauses and should subsequently refer this matter to the Standing Committee on Industry and Trade so that that Committee can examine the proposed establishment of inward duty-free shops and its impact on Customs administration and barrier control. We have a duty to do that, for to do otherwise is to be careless.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I still do not think that Senator Chaney understands the mechanisms of these Bills. These Bills will take in revenue from the concessionaires which will be used to offset against all air navigation charges. I do not think that Senator Chaney understands that; he still seems to imply that it is only offset for international costs. That will not be so. It will be offset against all air navigation charges. It is obvious that he has not studied this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier, Senator Puplick raised the item of small business. It is difficult for me to see how any small business can be affected when the only three items involved are perfume, liquor and cigarettes. These are items which would have been bought in Singapore or some other place anyway. It is interesting to note, incidentally, that this is not a unique idea. It will not be used only in Australia. Singapore, a very major embarkation point for Australian flights, and Taiwan, Pakistan, India, Sri Lanka, and New Zealand may use it. New Zealand is about to implement this type of inward duty-free shopping. So, we shall not be alone. It is not something that somehow the Government has just cooked up as a hare-brained scheme. This has been studied. It is working elsewhere. It has been proven.

The other item is tourism. Strong support for inward duty-free shopping is shown by the tourist industry, by representatives and commissions. They feel that Australia's present reputation as a shopping destination would be significantly enhanced by this proposal. The tourist industry feels that if we can make Australia a more attractive destination, through this and other means, more tourists will come here and spend more money in Australia, thus enhancing small business. Any increases in tourism resulting from these incentives will have a multiplier effect on our economy as a whole.

We have heard once again about problems of Customs control. This is an overall problem in Australia, as in any other country where drugs flow across borders. For the life of me, I cannot see why this one issue can cause so much of a problem, so much of an increase in drugs. These duty-free shops are basically warehouses which are licensed and controlled by Customs. They are controlled in terms of the warehousing provisions contained in Part V of the Customs Act 1901. They will be required to be licensed as Customs warehouses. It is nothing unusual. The licensing of these premises will require compliance with certain eligibility criteria relating to the physical security of the premises, the safekeeping of the goods in the warehouse where there is a duty-free shop operator, the maintenance by the duty-free operator of proper records, being records sufficient to trace the movement of those goods out of the warehouse by sale to a passenger, and the need to be able to satisfactorily account to Customs for their warehouse goods. The Customs administration of the warehousing arrangements for the scheme of restricted duty free shopping is feasible. There can be no major problems which are insurmountable by the very capable people in the Customs Service. To amend this Bill further it is really unnecessary. I feel that we have canvassed the issues quite thoroughly. To carry the argument any further would simply be an improper use of the Committee's time, so I will sit down and make no further remarks. I hope that we can get on with the rest of the business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take only a moment to respond to a couple of the extraordinary remarks made by Senator Sanders. By way of interjection he dismissed the Treasury's Industries Assistance Commission claim as rubbish. The claim that the Treasury made before the IAC was that it would be `ludicrous' to believe that the savings alleged to occur as a result of inward duty free shopping would have any overall impact when we consider the total revenue forgone as a result of its introduction. For Senator Sanders to dismiss that Treasury statement as rubbish I think simply indicates that he has not read, studied or understood the Treasury's submission to the Industries Assistance Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sanders's second point related to the alleged enormous fuel saving. Let me take him back to the September 1979 Bureau of Transport Economics report entitled `Inwards Duty-Free Shopping at Australian International Air Terminals: An economic evaluation'. Under the heading `Fuel Savings' it is said, among other things:

Allowing for these adjustments the estimate of total fuel cost saving ranges from $54,000 in 1980 to $163,000 in 1982. These savings are small and would be an insignificant part of the total operating costs of any international airline providing services into Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —A penny saved is a penny earned.

—A penny saved is a penny earned, and a life lost as a result of increased drug smuggling is a life lost. Senator Sanders should stick to saving his grubby pennies and let the Opposition parties stick to trying to save young lives. Senator Sanders said for heavens sake, `this is going to make Australia a more attractive tourist destination'. He thinks that the ability to buy a bottle of liquor, 200 cigarettes and a small amount of perfume will make Australia a more attractive shopping destination. He thinks that people will sit on an aeroplane for hours and hours because it is more attractive to buy a bottle of liquor when they get to Sydney Airport. Those people will probably be coming from places where it is cheaper to buy in any case. Let Senator Sanders remember this: What has made Australian duty free shopping renowned throughout the world has been the phenomenal success of the off-airport duty free shops.
—Most of them are rip-off merchants.
—The very people who are the most likely to be affected by the introduction of inward duty free--
—What quantities of booze do they sell at those shops?
—In some cases about a third of their total income is made up from that. Senator Chipp says that most of them are rip-off merchants.
—That is what I said, yes.

—He did indeed. Let me take the honourable senator to the latest Choice survey. Perhaps he will have some respect for the survey done in the November 1985 Choice magazine. The report on that survey in the Australian for 9-10 November 1985 said:

SPEECH.PARA: An international survey of duty-free shopping has revealed that most Australian stores-except at Sydney Airport-compare favourably with European and Asian competitors.

Mr Temporary Chairman, I wish through you to address remarks to Senator Chipp, if Senator Button will yield his ear to me for one moment. I wish to address this remark to Senator Chipp, through the Temporary Chairman. The article-

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not interested.
—He is not in the least bit interested in listening. The Australian article, having said how Australian duty free shopping was the best in the world, said:

SPEECH.PARA: `The only exception (was) Sydney Airport's duty-free which had noticeably higher alcohol and cigarette prices.'

They are the very people who are now to be given the sole monopoly concession in Sydney to sell cigarettes and tobacco. The only people who charge internationally high prices, who are genuine rip-off merchants-the people who are operating the store at Sydney Airport-are the people to whom this legislation gives the monopoly concession. All of the others, according to the article headed `Duty-free shopping', in Choice of November 1985, are demonstrated by international comparison to be among the cheapest in the world. I think the lack of logic in Senator Chipp's point is totally revealed.

I address a question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). I ask him in his reply to indicate to the Committee what extra resources are to be made available to the Australian Customs Service for the surveillance of passengers in the inward duty-free shopping area. The last point I make is this: If Senator Chipp has any reputation in this chamber, it has been one of being very sensitive to the recommendations of the Bureau of Customs-now the Australian Customs Service-for what it believes to be in the interests of Australians in matters of narcotics control. Senator Chipp has a long-established reputation in this place for having paid the closest attention to the recommendations of the Customs Bureau. I appeal to him, therefore, not to go back on that reputation and to stick by the Customs Service in this matter. Consistently, in every inquiry, as shown in the report of the Bureau of Transport Economics, in interdepartmental committee reports, in the report of the Mahony Review of Customs Administration and Procedures and in the IAC report, Customs has pleaded with the Government not to introduce inward duty free shopping. I plead with Senator Chipp once again to give his support to the recommendations of the Australian Customs Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Puplick's question is that a number of additional Customs officers were made available earlier this year for general surveillance duties. There has, of course, been no special allocation in respect of inward duty free shopping, as there is yet no legislation in respect of inward duty free shopping. I indicate that the Government does not accept the Opposition's argument for reasons given earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the clauses and Schedule stand as printed:

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bills-by leave-taken as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to Schedule 6 in Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985, which refers to metal working machine tools and the increase in duty from 2 per cent to 25 per cent. I thank the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) for his response, which went so far as to outline the procedures which are available to importers to obtain commercial tariff concessions where the spare parts are not manufactured in Australia. I ask the Minister whether he is able to give a commitment that the Government will expedite these applications. There is concern in the industry about delay. I ask him to give that simple undertaking that that will be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will certainly give that undertaking in respect of the parts covered by this legislation. The concern may go wider than that, but insofar as these Bills are concerned, I give that undertaking.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment or request; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Button) read a third time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference to Standing Committee on Industry and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Industry and Trade: The proposed establishment of inwards duty free shops, and its impact on Customs administration and barrier control.

I do not wish to speak to this motion at length. I simply say to the Senate, for the benefit of the Australian Democrats, that this motion will not delay the legislation, the legislation having passed through the third reading. It would enable the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade to look at the administration and to check the issues which are of concern to the Opposition and report back to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you spoken to the Chairman of the Committee?
—The Committee is aware that the matter has been raised.
—How does the Committee feel about the idea?

—I am sorry, all I know is that the Committee Chairman has been advised. In any event, there is a significant matter which the Australian Customs Service has raised as an issue. I think it would be reasonable for the Senate to look at it. It would mean that if there were resource problems, for example, it would be more likely that the Government would be under pressure to meet them. I think this would be a useful way of seeing that we do not have the sorts of problems with barrier control that have caused the Opposition to oppose parts of this legislation. I do not think there can be any doubt, given the attitude of the Customs Service, that there are potential problems. We would like to see that those problems are, at least, examined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government deoes not support the view put by Senator Chaney. The substantive issues have been argued in the course of this cognate debate. It would be nice to refer everything a government does to a committee to make sure that the Government does things properly. I assure Senator Chaney that if there is an additional need for resources we will look after that. I would be very concerned that that was so. We do not accept the motion for those reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

Question resolved in the affirmative.

(2) Clause 10, page 4, lines 15 to 42, omit proposed sub-section 25 (7), substitute the following sub-section:

Motion (by Senator Button) proposed:
That the amendments be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the fact that there has been consultation between the Government and the Opposition. I thank the Government for that and also Senator Walsh's staff. Senator Button has to put down the reasons in a form of words which both the Government and the Opposition have agreed to. I will not be opposing the legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been discussions about this legislation. I give notice that it is intended to amend sub-section 25 (7) of the principal Act along the lines of ensuring that there is consultation with the Parliament on the contents of guidelines. An appropriate mechanism would be to require that the guidelines on annual reports should be approved by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. In the meantime, the Government undertakes, before introducing revised guidelines, to seek their approval by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to point out that the Australian Democrats were involved in the tripartite negotiations. We moved the original amendment, which was in fact disallowed in the other House, to make certain that the annual reporting procedures were forced upon departments and statutory bodies and that standards and guidelines of some type were set in. As a result of the negotiations, we accept the Government's undertaking to put the amendment that Senator Button has told us about into the next Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Amendment Bill and the Australian Democrats will be supporting that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: BOUNTY (COMMERCIAL MOTOR VEHICLES) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985[COGNATE BILL:SUBSIDY (GRAIN HARVESTERS AND EQUIPMENT) BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 November, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the Senate that this Bill and the Subsidy (Grain Harvesters and Equipment) Bill 1985 be taken cognately? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose either of the two Bills we are now debating cognately, namely, the Bounty (Commercial Motor Vehicles) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985 and the Subsidy (Grain Harvesters and Equipment) Bill 1985. However, there are a few points I would like to make on each of the Bills on behalf of the Opposition. The Bounty (Commercial Motor Vehicles) Bill is part of a package of revised assistance arrangements for the commercial motor vehicle industry in Australia which was announced by the Government in August, the overall effect of which will be a modest reduction in the level of assistance afforded the local industry. The Bill before the Senate at the moment proposes the phasing out, over a three-year period commencing on 1 January 1986, of bounty assistance on certain components used in the assembly of general purpose heavy commercial motor vehicles with a gross weight of 2.72 tonnes or more. The tariff assistance to be provided, phasing up from the present nil to 25 per cent by 1 January 1989, will be balanced by a reduction in the bounty assistance as the existing bounty is phased down over the same period from its 20 per cent to nil.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has explained in the second reading speech of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) that the basic reason for this change is to effect a rationalisation in the industry, particularly so far as component manufacturers are concerned. This is a very fragmented industry. It has had a checkered history both in terms of the assistance accorded to it and in terms of its own activities. I think there is general agreement on all sides that it is a very important and worthwhile part of our total manufacturing base, but one which would benefit from measures taken to improve its overall efficiency by helping it to rationalise.

Whilst not opposing the Government's proposal, I do not fully understand exactly how the switch from bounty to tariff is going to effect that rationalisation. In the debate in the other House the Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Mr Barry Jones), who handled the Bill there, tried to make the point, I think incorrectly, that putting on a tariff instead of bounty assistance would make the imported product 25 per cent more expensive than the locally-produced product and that that, therefore, would cause more local production. It seems to me that that is a technically incorrect argument, particularly given that the Government says that this level of assistance being afforded in this Bill, this time by way of a tariff, will be roughly equivalent to the level of assistance now being afforded by way of bounty. I would appreciate some clarification from the Minister on that point because prima facie it would also appear that taking away a bounty and imposing a tariff has the disadvantage of increasing costs to users and generally lifting the level of cost in Australia. In that sense, of course, there is an inconsistency in the Government's approaches to the two Bills we are presently debating because the other Bill, the Subsidy (Grain Harvesters and Equipment) Bill, moves in the direction of assistance of a tariff nature being replaced by a bounty. What we are debating cognately are two Bills which, in terms of the nature of the assistance to be afforded, are moving in quite opposite directions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without going away from protection.

—Without going away from protection, but it is a different form of barrier assistance, of course. The reason for the grain subsidy Bill before us is nothing other than a very cynical political exercise on the part of the Government.
—Why is it cynical? Your leader here has been advocating today the same thing in respect of diesel rebates. What is cynical about that?

—The reason it is cynical is that only two years ago the Government introduced a 15 per cent tariff on imported grain harvesters and until earlier this year the Government's thinking on assistance to this industry had been entirely along the lines of tariff assistance. What produced the change in heart on the Government's part, a change I hasten to add which we do not oppose, was pressure by the Opposition and by the rural sector on the Government to do something about controlling the horrendous, massive and very widely based cost increases that the rural sector in this country has been facing as a result of a whole range of policies of this Government. As a result of that, the Government announced, following discussions with the National Farmers Federation, that it would mount an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into how to change the existing tariff assistance into bounty assistance without affecting the overall level of assistance for the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner we were discussing the Subsidy (Grain Harvesters and Equipment) Bill and the Bounty (Commercial Motor Vehicles) Amendment Bill (No. 2). In relation to the former Bill I was outlining the background to the reasons why the Government has made the proposals that are now before the House, proposals which, as I said, the Opposition supports. The basic reason for those proposals goes back to earlier this year when the Government, under pressure from the Opposition and the rural sector-the National Farmers Federation, the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation and others-at last got the message from them that the farm cost increases that had been occurring in Australia over the last couple of years were really crippling the domestic industry. For that reason the Government, with the support of the Opposition, sent a reference to the Industries Assistance Commission, to provide assistance-without changing the overall assistance available to the industry-to grain harvesters in the form of a bounty rather than the existing tariff level. The Bill reflects that.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the Opposition supports the Bill. We are sorry that it is being debated in such haste. We are sorry that the IAC was required to investigate and report on the matter with such haste and we are sorry that the original proposal came from a political exercise rather than a considered view as to what was in the best interests of the industry in Australia, although the outcome is obviously and supportively, from our view, in the best interests of the user industries. As I said before the dinner break, there is a conflict and an inconsistency in the Government's approach to these two Bills. In one case we are moving from bounty assistance to tariff assistance. In the case of the other Bill we are moving from tariff assistance to bounty assistance. That is an inconsistency. I believe that inconsistency raises the whole question of the Government's approach towards the direction in which industry restructuring and industry development in Australia should be going.

There are obviously many more factors involved in industry development than just the question of tariffs or bounties, important though they are. If we are serious about restructuring a developing industry in Australia we have to look at a much wider range of issues. We have to look at the whole question of the basic competitiveness of Australian industry. That can be affected in an artificial way by the question of whether we provide assistance in the form of bounties or whether we provide it in the form of tariffs. However, in many respects that is an artificial question. When we deal with industry assistance Bills we ought to be looking at what we need to do in Australia in terms of making this nation, and particularly our manufacturing sector, more competitive. Whether we are going to be able to compete in an increasingly world oriented market scene depends in the end on costs, efficiency, competitiveness and many other things.

This is an important issue which involves an attitudinal approach towards industry and towards where we are going as a nation. Unless we are really serious about wanting to reduce our costs and to become more competitive, if we really want to have a manufacturing sector in this country-and this is certainly a basic aim of the Opposition and, I believe, of the Government as well-and unless we are really serious at a government, political, industry, union and management level about looking at and diagnosing what is wrong in this country in terms of where we are going in industry, we are never really going to solve the problems in front of us.

As I have said, the Opposition does not oppose the two Bills before the Senate. I believe the Bills raise certain particular issues in terms of whether the Government is being consistent in its approach. However, both of the Bills trend in the right direction and for that reason, as I said earlier, the Opposition does not oppose them. I have raised various issues which I hope either the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who is in the chamber at the moment, or, more particularly the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) will deal with when summing up the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is dealing cognately with the Bounty (Commercial Motor Vehicles) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985 and the Subsidy (Grain Harvesters and Equipment) Bill 1985. At present, assistance in respect of heavy commercial vehicles is provided by a mixture of bounty protection and tariff protection. The Bounty (Commercial Motor Vehicles) Amendment Bill (No. 2) does not seek to increase protection, but rather seeks to change the type of protection that is available. The Industries Assistance Commission report which was referred to by Senator Short, who has just concluded his speech, recommended that the bounty on parts be replaced with an increased tariff on completed vehicles. It also recommended that there be a tariff protection for various component parts. This would certainly result in less protection for the part producers and assemblers and increased prices for consumers. Hence, we believe that the approach the Government has taken has a lot to recommend it. We certainly do not want to see any increased protection within the economy and the Government, by making use of the device of a bounty rather than the protection mechanism is, we believe, heading in the right direction.

SPEECH.PARA: The development of the support which is necessary for Australia's manufacturing industry has to be based on the grounds of competitiveness with world industry and not, as it were, as though it existed in a world of its own. It should exist in the competitive market-place. Of course, other approaches can be taken. Hopefully, in the new year the Government will look at taking further approaches with regard to the support of industry. My colleague Senator John Siddons's Employee Participation Bill, we believe, would be of help in regard to this further development of industry by bringing the employees and employers within industry closer together, rather than as is currently the case in an across the board union-employer organisation, which often does not have terribly much to do with what the person does in his day-to-day work place.

I also indicate the support of the Australian Democrats for the second of the Bills, the Subsidy (Grain Harvesters and Equipment) Bill. But we wish to raise a particular problem with the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button. There are currently three manufacturers of grain harvesters in Australia. The largest of those manufacturers is a wholly-owned Australian company in South Australia. It currently employs, as I understand it, about 270 people and is indirectly responsible for about 1,250 jobs. The Government's Bill as it is currently structured plans to replace the present 15 per cent tariff on imported grain harvesters with a subsidy. That subsidy is broken down into two parts: A subsidy of 12 1/2 per cent of sale value if the value added by the manufacturer is not less than 40 per cent; and, in other cases, the subsidy is to be 25 per cent of the value added by the manufacturer.

The South Australian producer, the largest producer in Australia, produces two types of harvester-the self-propelled harvester and the power take-off. Fifty per cent of its output is in the area of the self-propelled harvester. But the self-propelled harvester has a local value added, according to the manufacturer, of only 38 to 39 per cent, which, of course, is below the threshold for the maximum subsidy. The reason for the fact that the value added is below the threshold is that the work carried out by Australian subcontractors under this legislation is not considered for value added purposes. Of course, the subcontractors get the bounty as part suppliers. Hence, the company in South Australia has claimed that it will get no advantage from the Government's subsidisation of parts and has sought from the Government a variety of possible ways of dealing with its problem. Essentially, its solution boils down to this: The Government would extend the bounty to production for export, as it does for other industries.

The Australian Democrats do not support that type of approach. We do not believe that the subsidisation of our exports in the long term is likely to do other than harm Australia as a whole. Already, of course, Australia is locked in fairly heavy competition in the international scene. If Australia argued with the European Economic Community and the American markets, that they ought to wind back their heavy subsidisation, it would hardly be useful for us to start aggressively to subsidise our products and expect them to take very much notice. It does not, I think, in the long run assist any country to engage in that activity. So we do not believe that is an avenue which is available.

Another possible approach, of course, is to count sub-contracting work in the total Australian value added formula. Since the sub-contracting work is value added in terms of the bounty formula contained in this Bill, we would be looking at a double bounty and that would hardly seem to be an advisable way to travel. The only avenue which seems to be left is that contained within the Bill, and is within the discretion of the Government. I refer to clause 13 of the legislation, which allows the Government to set a new percentage for eligibility criteria. Because this is possible and because we believe in this case that we are dealing with only three manufacturers over the whole of Australia, we certainly seek from the Government its response to this problem. If we were dealing with hundreds of manufacturers, that would obviously not be a reasonable request to put to the Government. As I understand it, Senator Button is already very conversant with this problem, and I would be interested in hearing in his summing up the Government's view on how it will handle that problem. Senator Button is looking quizzical at the moment. I do not intend to go through the entire episode again; I merely refer Senator Button to the Horwood Bagshaw Ltd problem in South Australia.

I must admit that I cannot see how one could criticise these Bills, as did the previous speaker, by suggesting that they are going in the opposite direction. I suggest that they are both going in the right direction, one possibly not as far as the other. Any movement away from the protection mechanisms that have been entrenched in the past and have been massively used, to more open forms of support, first of all to a subsidy operation and then to a bounty operation, needs to be welcomed. I think it is not really fair of the Opposition spokesperson in this debate to criticise the Government for moving in this way when it is the Opposition's policy to move in the same way. When it was in government, so little was done in these areas.

I indicate that the Australian Democrats will support both of these pieces of legislation, and I will be interested in seeking from the Minister the attitude the Government is likely to take on clause 13 of the grain harvester legislation and whether or not the Government will be seeking to alter at any stage the percentage eligibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their fulsome support of the Bounty (Commercial Motor Vehicles) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Subsidy (Grain Harvesters and Equipment) Bill. However, a couple of questions have arisen in the course of the debate to which I wish to refer. Senator Macklin raised a question in his comments on the grain harvester bounty legislation. It is perfectly true that the company in South Australia to which he referred rather circumspectly-I am not sure that he mentioned its name; it was Horwood Bagshaw Ltd-did raise some doubts about the larger harvester produced by them qualifying for the 12.5 per cent outward subsidy because the value added in the production of the machine was below the 40 per cent eligibility threshold.

SPEECH.PARA: Since those doubts were raised, the management of Horwood Bagshaw has been to Canberra and has had lengthy discussions with officers in my Department. As a result, the company is reassessing its position. It certainly looks as though it would not be as disadvantageous as was expressed in its earlier representations. There are arrangements for ongoing discussions on that question. I do not think there is any point in my anticipating the details of those discussions at this stage.

Senator Short raised the question of the switch from bounty to tariff in respect of certain components referred to in the Bounty (Commercial Motor Vehicles) Amendment Bill. Of course, he is quite correct in stating that there does not seem to be any difference in the level of assistance accorded currently to bountiable components through switching from a bounty to a tariff. Certainly the Government has not claimed any such reduction.

The level of assistance, however, where there is a difference, is that accorded to the assembly operation, which is reduced by this change. Where assemblers are currently being paid bounty at the rate of 20 per cent for the use of those components, under the new arrangements these payments will phase out and assemblers using locally sourced components will be faced with a phased increase in the cost of these components of up to 20 per cent, while assemblers using imported components will face a phased increase in the cost of their components of up to 25 per cent. This is one of the measures we have taken to reduce the high level of assistance accorded the assembly sector, which is currently around 95 per cent in effective rate terms, down to an estimated 65 per cent.

So there is a substantial reduction in assistance to the assembly operation. This applies, of course, only to those currently bountiable components on which phased tariffs are to be introduced. I must say to Senator Short, that in terms of the problem of this particular industry, we have had that debate before in the Senate. It is a very difficult industry with which to grapple, but I assure Senator Short that in terms of the assembly operations it represents a considerable reduction in assistance.

Senator Short also sought to draw some inconsistency between the grain harvesters bounty and the phasing out of the bounty for commercial motor vehicles. Any apparent difference in approach arises from the difference in intent of the two quite separate measures. The grain harvesters bounty is aimed at reducing the cost to users. The Senate is aware of the circumstances in which it was announced, and in fact we have been chided for that in the course of debate here. The beneficiaries of that are the farm sector. The phasing out of the commercial motor vehicle bounty is, as I have already stated, to reduce the current high level of assistance accorded to the assembly sector of the commercial motor vehicle industry, such as it is. I think they were the two matters of substance with which I had to deal. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are just two or three points I would like to raise in relation to specific clauses of the Bill. Before I do that, I reiterate that the Opposition does not criticise the direction in which the Government is taking the grain harvesters Bill. I did not express opposition at all to the bounty arrangements. I chided-to use Senator Button's word-the Government on the motivation for the move that has taken place, rather than the move itself. I am not saying that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) should not have imposed the bounty in relation to the grain harvesters; I am questioning the motivation for doing so. There are two or three brief comments that I would like to make in relation to specific clauses of the Bill. The first relates to the definition of the interpretation clause, clause 4.
—Which Bill is this?
—The Subsidy (Grain Harvesters and Equipment) Bill. I refer to the interpretation of `production service' which is at the top of page 3. Production service includes, under (d):

SPEECH.PARA: a service declared by the regulations to be a production service for the purposes of this Act;

I think I am correct in saying that that has relevance to the question of the treatment of subcontractors. The Industries Assistance Commission report on this subject at page 15, section 3.4.2 says that in calculating the bounty, it is desirable that provision be made to allow for the value of such services; that is, the services of subcontractors. As I understand it, the Bill before us at the moment does not take up that recommendation or expression of opinion by the IAC, but there is provision for it to be taken up through the interpretation clause-clause 4 of the Bill.

I would like an assurance from the Minister that my interpretation is correct because I think it is an important point. If what we are about is the increasing of local Australian involvement in the production of both components and finished products within the industry, obviously the role of the subcontractor can be very important indeed. In fact, it may be critical for some of the major assembler and producer companies who may wish to increase the Australian content in their product but for whom it is not financially or economically viable or worth while to do so by setting up a new production facility, whereas they could benefit, and Australian industry as a whole could benefit, by the greater use of sub-contractors. To give an example of that, a case which comes readily to mind because I have had connection with it in the past in a representational sense is A. F. Gayson Pty Ltd at Ararat, which makes harvester cabins. They would be a subcontractor to a company like Horwood Bagshaw Ltd, but at the moment they do not appear, other than through clause 4, to be covered in the legislation. I just raise that and I would be grateful for any comment the Minister may have because what is proposed in this Bill does not seem to me to take on board what the IAC proposed and recommended in that respect.

The other two clauses of the Bill I would like to refer to briefly are clauses 10 and 13. I am really seeking guidance on this. Clause 10 relates to the specification of subsidy and in clause 10 (3) there seems to me and to the Opposition that there is an inconsistency between the drafting of paragraphs (a) and (b). The clause does not appear to make sense unless one includes in (a) the word `or' before one comes to (b). The two paragraphs tend to be mutually exclusive. I understand that there has been some discussion with the Department about that but I am not satisfied that an adequate explanation has been given as to how paragraphs (a) and (b) of clause 10 (3) of the Bill can sit together if there is not the word `or' between the two. I would be grateful for comment on that.
The only other comment I want to make is in relation to clause 13 of the Bill. I note that clause 13 (1) (a) states:
The subsidy payable under section 10 in respect of a subsidised harvester to the completion manufacturer of the harvester is-
(a) where the value added to the harvester by the completion manufacturer is not less than 40 per cent, or, if another percentage is pre- scribed . . .

The clause continues. I would like an assurance from the Minister regarding the discussions that I think have been held outside this chamber in relation to one of the companies that is involved-involved in the sense of being affected very significantly by this Bill-that in fact, depending on the arithmetic involved in the calculation of value added, if this causes a problem in relation to the 40 per cent figure, which I cited, in clause 13 (1) (a), the following words `or if another percentage is prescribed' will be taken into consideration by the Government, or I guess by the Department, in looking at the actual payment arrangements. I would welcome some satisfaction or confirmation of those points.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the last point first. Of course, the provisions in clause 13 (1) of the Bill will be taken into account if appropriate. The Department will endeavour to meet the problem. I do not wish to elevate the provisions of that clause as the only solution to the problem. I make it quite clear that that is not the only solution to the problem. With regard to clause 10, the provisions to which Senator Short referred are cumulative. As I understand it, there is no detriment to sub-contractors in those provisions being so cumulative. With regard to clause 4, Senator Short asked about the definition of `production services'. He referred particularly to sub-clause (d); that is, a `service declared by the regulations to be a production service for the purposes of this Act'. He asked whether that embraced the position of sub-contractors, if that is the right expression. The answer to that question is that it may well do. The sub-contractors of the kind that he mentioned, such as A. F. Gayson Pty Ltd, are in a position to obtain the bounty in any event in their own right by application under this legislation. But that provision possibly could be interpreted in the way he suggested.

—I thank the Minister for his response. I will ponder on the latter part. I was not necessarily commenting on clause 10 (3) in relation to sub-contractors. It was just in terms of the straight logic of the drafting of the clause. It would appear that 10 (3) (a) is a different requirement from 10 (3) (b) and that, therefore, the word `or' ought to appear between (a) and (b). If the word `or' does not appear, (a) and (b) read together do not appear to make sense. That was my point.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, this is a standard provision in most bounty legislation of this kind. The instruction I have is that they are considered to be cumulative. It is a matter of interpretation whether they can be seen to be in this category. Clause 10 (3) (a) requires all the processes to be carried out in registered premises; clause 10 (3) (b) requires that the last substantial process in the manufacture of the equipment be carried out in registered premises. All it means is that both of those requirements must be satisfied. It seems almost tautologous, but it is a standard requirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is my point. Unless the word `or' is between the two clauses, clause 10 (3) (b) is tautologous in that it is completely unnecessary.
—If you put `or' in, see how it reads. You have a problem with (b).
—I think you have a problem with clause 10 (3) (b) whichever way one reads it.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement in connection with a notice of motion standing in my name for the disallowance of part of an ordinance.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has been scrutinising the Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 3) 1985. The Ordinance has the effect that any person accused of a criminal offence involving money or property of less than $2,500 in value has no right to trial by a jury. Such a person would be tried summarily by a magistrate unless the magistrate otherwise ordered. The Committee wrote to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) raising this matter as an issue of concern. The right to trial by jury in indictable cases is central to our criminal justice system. In 1951 the right of an accused person to be tried by jury was removed in respect of certain indictable offences, the test being whether the property involved had a money value of below #100. In 1974 that value was raised to $500. This year there was a move to raise it to $2,500.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to report that the Attorney-General has given an undertaking to amend the Ordinance to provide that a person charged with a relevant criminal offence shall not be tried summarily unless the person consents to that course. I therefore withdraw Business of the Senate, notice of motion No. 1, as amended earlier today, standing in my name for this day of sitting for disallowance of part of the Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 3) 1985. In doing so I pay tribute to the Attorney-General for the undertaking he has given on this matter. The Committee viewed the right to trial by jury as a matter of vital significance to it under its principle. The Attorney-General, by his undertaking, has recognised the importance of the issue and he deserves our thanks and approbation for his decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator stated that he was withdrawing a notice of motion. Is this the last day on which disallowance is possible? Is there not a special procedure in the Senate?
—Senator Cooney, if you wish to withdraw a notice of motion you must seek leave. You have not done so yet. Do you wish to do this?
—Yes, I seek leave. This is the last day on which I can move such a motion to withdraw the notice of motion. I seek leave, if that is the right procedure, to do so.
—Is leave granted? There being no objection--

—I have no objection, but as I recall it, if leave is granted and any other senator wishes to persist, that honourable senator will lose his right. Does the honourable senator know whether both sides of the House are happy with the withdrawal?
—Yes. This has been agreed to in the Committee. I thank the honourable senator for raising that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Notice of motion-by leave-withdrawn.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 3 December, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
