I wrote to the Foreign Minister and asked for a draft copy of the code of conduct to be offered to me on similar terms to those under which it was offered to Senator Missen by Senator Evans. The Foreign Minister wrote back and said that I could not have it on the same terms; I could not have it at all. The code of conduct was released to the media first without Parliament having had the opportunity to debate it first.

Senator Evans, who is at the table, might think that that is acceptable. Ministers in other governments might think that it is acceptable. I do not think that it is acceptable. I think it is extraordinary that the Foreign Minister chooses to give one senator a different answer from the answer which the senator representing him in the Senate chooses to give. That is just one example. Another example is that the other day significant changes to government in the Australian Capital Territory were announced, not to Parliament but in a stage managed Press conference. I noticed that Senator Reid drew attention to this matter and expressed regret that it had been done in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —How else do you expect people to find out?

—One could go on-one is tempted to go on by the interjections from the other side of the chamber-with the long list of examples. Nonetheless, as I said, I have undertaken to be brief and I will leave the examples at those two. I have indicated that I do not believe that it is only this Government; previous governments also have undertaken this practice. I also think that the media cannot avoid criticism for the way in which Parliament is conducted and for the invitation that they offer to members of parliament to be lured into their net. The net about which I speak is one that invites senators and members to engage in side-shows, if you like, as though senators and members were here to amuse members of the Press Gallery. It is not my belief that that is the function of senators and members; nonetheless in some cases that seems to be what the media want. I draw the attention of the Senate to an article in the Canberra Times on Tuesday of this week, written by Debbie Cameron, with the headline `Senate is not a sideshow'. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate was sitting yesterday without the distraction of the thespian House of Representatives and the public galleries were fuller than usual. What a cruel surprise for the busloads of pensioners and school children shuttled to Parliament House expecting to see a lacerating diatribe from the Treasurer, Mr Keating, or a fumbling impersonation of Max Gillies from the Prime Minister. What did they get? The Senate.
It fails miserably as a sideshow. No clowns, no whizzing moments of terror, no giddy laughter and no sparkling spruikers.

I simply make the point to Ms Cameron, and I suppose to Ian Warden who wrote an article which has a headline `Knitting in the land of nod', complaining about how boring it was to be covering the Senate, that the function of the Senate is not to be of interest to the Press Gallery, nor should it be. The job of members of the Press Gallery, in my view, is to report to the electors in this country what happens in both Houses of Parliament. If they think that it is boring, I do not mind their saying that it is boring. I do mind the expectation that this chamber and the other place be turned into some sort of side-show.

I am tempted to use, and I will use, one other example. I think that it is the most glaring example of the year of the release of a policy to the media before releasing it to Parliament; that was this Government's so-called Priority One: Young Australia policy. We have seen advertisements, similar to the one I found in the newspaper today, with a big picture of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke-I can understand why the Age refers to him as `Old Silver'-advertising himself yet again and advertising a policy that has not been properly thought out and debated in Parliament. I can understand why it was not debated in the Parliament before it was released, or at least canvassed in Parliament before it was released; the details were not even properly worked out. One can find that out by ringing any Commonwealth Employment Service office around the country and asking what it has in Priority One for young Australians. Any CES office will tell one that it does not have a damned thing; it has just been worked out. It has just been worked out. Old Silver, as Michelle Grattan refers to the Prime Minister, chose to release this policy prematurely to give himself a bit of advertising to create the impression that this Government is doing something about young Australians. That is yet another example of this Government-along with other governments-bypassing the role of Parliament to scrutinise policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must admit I am quite stunned by the contribution of Senator Vanstone but I will not comment any more on it. I want to speak very briefly about a superannuation case that has been presented to me. I do so in the context of the debate that is going on at the moment about who is competent and responsible enough to handle superannuation funds. It has been contended in this place and also publicly that the trade union movement is not competent to do this. The point I wish to make tonight in highlighting a particular instance of a constituent, not of mine but someone in Victoria, is that the trade union movement may be a more responsible body to handle superannuation funds than those who have been charged with the specific responsibility to date.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise the problem relating to the late Ian Macquarie, who died recently leaving three children all under the age of 14. He died after many years of work with his company. He stuck with his company after a takeover and worked for it assiduously and consistently. On the termination of his employment his superannuation payout was calculated. His family received $104,000. The problem is that there is a disputed amount of $8,000. One might think that $100,000 is enough and $8,000 should be seen as petty cash and not be argued about. But to a mother of three children left to guard and look after her children and bring them up it is obvious that $8,000 is, and will be, important to her.

What is disputed in this case is the date of termination of employment. Ian Macquarie was entitled to four times his eligible salary at the date of total and permanent disability. Under the superannuation agreement and trust deed that was operating in his case, the trustees of the deed deemed his date of ceasing active employment as 16 January 1984. On 20 September 1984 they wrote a letter to that effect. However, after that date Ian Macquarie went to work, was tested for employability, and continued working.

The main reason why the trustees saw 16 January 1984 as the date of termination of employment was that Macquarie soon after that date signed a declaration stating that he felt that he was unable to work as from 16 January 1984. It should be noted that he signed the declaration at a time when he was totally distressed. He had just been advised that he was dying of cancer and as a consequence his mental stability was diminished. However, having signed such a form, he was allowed to go back to work. As has been acknowledged in correspondence from the FSE scientific superannuation plan, he was able to go back to work and in fact worked until 25 May 1984. Ian Macquarie declared that he was unable to work on 16 January 1984. He did not declare that he was totally and permanently disabled on that date. By his employer's later actions it is quite apparent that they felt there was some chance he was able to to work after 16 January. In correspondence of 20 September 1984 the FSE stated that Mr Macquarie's employer subsequently terminated his employment on 25 May 1984. This date is important because the difference of those four months means that an amount of $8,000 has been denied to the widow and children of Ian Macquarie.

So, let me restate: Ian Macquarie was allowed to go back to work. He was tested by the company over a period, and then his employment was terminated. There was obviously some doubt, for four months, as to whether Macquarie could go back to work. There was obviously some doubt as to whether he was totally and permanently-I stress the word `permanently'-disabled for employment. That point was obviously known to the company and to the trustees of the superannuation fund.

It also should be noted that in correspondence to Senator Cooney dated 11 September 1985, it was recognised by the trustees that the date of disability was the date active work ceased. Let me restate that Ian Macquarie worked to 25 May 1984. Let me also state that in a report dated 1 March 1985, Macquarie's doctor declared that Macquarie was fit to return to work in April 1984.

What we have here is a situation in which the trustees-in this instance people who are directly, and probably with vested interests, involved in the operation of the company and the trust-have declared that Macquarie's eligible salary for the purpose of calculating superannuation was that accrued at 16 January 1984. Despite the fact that Macquarie went back to work, and despite all the other considerations I have mentioned, they denied that he was employable up to May 1984. As a consequence, his widow has been deprived of $8,000.

This decision by the trustees of the fund is a wrong one. In fact they have miscarried their duties, in my assessment of the situation and also on my reading of the fund. They have, in fact, relied on the technicality of the signature when, under the responsibilities of trustees, they should act both honestly and reasonably. In doing so, they would have recognised that Macquarie had returned to work, that his employer took him back on a trial basis, and that the declaration made by Macquarie, an error of fact, could not have been relied on by them as being fundamental in their decision making. They should also have recognised that his period of re-employment should have dissolved the effect of that declaration, signed by him, stating that he was not fit for work on 16 January.

What we have are trustees acting not honestly and reasonably but technically and outside the spirit of the trust and of operating legislation. As a consequence, we have them operating in the interests not of the beneficiary but soley in the interests of the companies involved in the trust. As a consequence, we have employers' representatives not acting fairly in the interests of the employee. Let us look at that in the context of the debate we have had today and in recent days in terms of superannuation trusts. I do not believe that the workers of this country ought to be at the whim of capricious trustees of trusts such as this one. I believe that Ian Macquarie's widow and children are entitled to the money. I believe that for the trustees to act behind a technicality is neither honest nor reasonable, and is a breach of their trust. I believe that the trustees have an obligation to review their decision once again.

In closing, let me say that I have tried today to contact Mr Townsend, a person who is a trustee of the fund, but without success. I will be contacting him in the next few days to alert him of my speech tonight and ask him to reconsider this decision made by the trustees. It is quite unfortunate that this position has been taken and has been adhered to by the trustees, but I hope that in the spirit of reasonableness they will review their decisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly in relation to the Australian Film Commission's annual report for 1985, which, notwithstanding the fact that my esteemed friend, as I would like to call him, Phillip Adams, is its part time Chairman, has done something which I regard as a matter which ought to be brought to the attention of the Senate and questioned. I have taken a considerable interest over a large number of years in the question of accountability and the nature of reporting to the Parliament. The Commission has presented a report by way of video. I produce in the chamber a videotape which it has supplied, as I understand it, to all members of the Parliament as a report.

SPEECH.PARA: I am curious, for several reasons, as to why the Commission should have done this. First, I am curious as to why it should regard the videotape as being a report which I could interpret. I do not happen to be one of those who possess a videotape player in their homes. In my experience, those who apply for legal aid tend to have one, but I know that a large number of other people do not have one. That might be regarded as a supercilious remark and, if so, I withdraw it. All I mean is that it is not something which is available in the home of every member of this chamber or of every member of this Parliament. The idea that a report should be made to the Parliament and to the people of Australia by way of a video presentation seems to me to indicate a quite obnoxious assumption that people have the necessary facilities. These facilities are obvoiusly appropriate and relevant to the Australian Film Commission but they are not available to a large percentage of Australians, and to them this form of report is inopportune.

I was curious also about the cost of that form of report. We are used to having reports printed in colour and sometimes in exotic colour. Certainly the Australian Film Commission, as one might expect, has indulged in exotic colour in the presentation of its fiscal printed report. I have no objection to that, but I wonder what the cost of the video presentation is. I asked some people who may have some idea about the cost. They told me that the cost of a similar video which was produced as a training video for people employed to perform commercial roles was between $35,000 and $38,000. I do not know what the cost of this video was but apparently it has been distributed to every member of the Parliament and to goodness knows how many other people as an annual report.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is actually a 10-year report.

—The interjection is that it is actually a 10-year report. I divide the cost by 10 and still ask whether it is warranted as a method of presenting a report when, apart from anything else, I personally, unless I queue up in the Senate party room and manage to get the use of the video machine there or go to one of my local television stations or something or other, will not be able to watch it. It does not mean a damn thing to me unless I do something like that. Quite frankly, it does not seem to me to be a way of reporting to the Parliament or to the people. After all, the report to the Parliament is a report to the people. I do not know how one translates what one has visually and auditiously accepted into a transmissible form. As I have said, notwithstanding my respect for the part time Chairman of the Commission, Phillip Adams-I quickly add that I have a very great respect for Phillip Adams--
—I don't think it is going to be reciprocated after tonight.

—I thank Senator Evans. I was going to go on to ask him whether he would apply somewhat less extravagant means of reporting in the future. It is interesting that Senator Evans should have interjected. I was going to mention one other matter in the adjournment debate. Earlier today I had occasion to take exception to the fact that I had been misrepresented in relation to certain comments I made about the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission. I note that we still have an outstanding problem in relation to CSL which neither Senator Evans nor I have concluded. It just so happen that I have the information with me. I will refer to it briefly. It is an article in the Bulletin entitled: `How bureaucratic venom threatens your life'. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Last week a new anti-venom saved the life of a boy bitten by a funnel-web spider. Yet a bureaucratic war in the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories means that only a few doeses are left to save spider victims-and that research has virtually ground to a halt.

I simply raise this question: When will we resolve how we deal with problems such as that? When will we resolve the problem about which I know-I say this, in no way provocatively-Senator Evans and I are genuinely concerned? Earlier today I spoke about certain aspects of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. I speak now about another one, and that is: How will we resolve the problems that arise in relation to the difference between commerciality and the need for research development, as exemplified in that instance?

I have raised two matters tonight. I will summarise them. Firstly, I have asked the Australian Film Commission to justify the cost of the video presentation of its annual report which I believe to be extravagant in the extreme and unrealistic in that it certainly will not get through to me and it is not likely to get through to a large number of other people. I have asked the Commission kindly to inform me whether I can return it so that it can be used for some other purpose. I have raised again the question of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and the problem of the reconciliation between research and administration.
Friday, 6 December 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had nine speakers so far tonight on the adjournment, an unhappy experience at the best of times made even more so by the existence of numerous end of session parties around the building tonight. I want to say, though, that at least some of those speakers made positive and substantial contributions. I refer in particular to the condolences very effectively expressed tonight by Senator Giles and Senator Chaney for the late Gloria Brennan who was known to many in this place and indeed to many people in political life and active public life around the country as a great activist in the Aboriginal cause. I share the sentiments expressed by the other senators. We will mourn her passing.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted but do not share the views expressed by Senator Michael Baume about the Senate in his contribution tonight. It was a sort of end of term report from the new boy after his first period in this place. I think the best answer to him came in a series of quotations in Senator Vanstone's speech about which she was expressing outrage but which seemed to me to capture quite precisely the essence of this institution. It is all there on the record, and I refer Senator Baume to Senator Vanstone's contribution in that respect.

As far as Senator Tate and Senator Kilgariff were concerned, we were treated to a sort of internecine war between two rival factions within the Catholic Church, an exchange reminiscent of nothing so much as the squabble between the Guelphs and the Ghibellines in sixteenth century Florence. Many other heresies no doubt will be perpetrated and allegations of heresies made, but mercifully we might be spared them in future in this place. The story of the Catholic Commission on Peace and Justice has all the hallmarks of an ongoing saga. I only hope that I will not be on duty during the adjournment debate the next time it gets an airing.

I am afraid that Senator Vigor's contribution on the perils of travel, personnel and freight on the Australian National Railways left us all rather agog with indifference. It was a speech, I am afraid to say, of quite excruciating tedium, although no doubt of some significance to someone. No doubt it can be referred to the appropriate source. At this time of night really I think it is a bit difficult to treat us to that kind of thing, although I understand the conviction with which the honourable senator espouses these causes.
Senator Bolkus advanced a superannuation matter, the substance of which speaks for itself, and no doubt it will be taken up in the appropriate places.

Senator Rae raised two particular matters. One was about the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission, the substance of which I cannot help but agree with him about based on my experience of fighting the battles on behalf of the spider venom man, Dr Struan Sutherland in the past. The CSL is an extraordinary institution and questions of accountability of administration continually there arise. I have much less sympathy, however, with Senator Rae's other contribution tonight, telling us how obnoxious he found the rather adventurous exercise by the Australian Film Commission in presenting its tenth anniversary report to the Parliament not in the form of a printed document, which no one is likely to read any more than these documents are ever read, but in the form of a video. I think Senator Rae, in attacking that presentation, displayed a quite remarkable and quite conspicuous lack of imagination which I hope is not going to be characteristic of his contributions in the future in the Tasmanian Parliament, should he succeed in making the transition there, although if he does continue to perform in that way he will be much more at home than was the case when expressing those qualities in this place. I think it is unfortunate to make the assumption that Senator Rae seems constantly to make that people actually read the annual reports about which he is so obsessed. I think the prospect of anyone taking some notice of an annual report in the form in which it circulated to us as a video is something we ought to greet with positive enthusiasm rather than with the distaste with which it was greeted tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does it not make of it a horrible waster of money if people do not take any notice?

—Maybe so, but if one added up the cost of the production, publication, printing and circulation of all the annual reports of all the statutory authorities that are circulated to all the people they go out to, it would, I suspect, be a quite gigantic impost on the public purse, and one might well ask for a cost benefit analysis of that too. It is quite extraordinary. I simply make the point that if annual reports are to be given at all, some credit ought to be given to an imaginative presentation rather than the kind of po faced dispatch with which this particular piece of adventure was greeted by the honourable senator tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, Senator Vanstone, in the course of her speech tonight about the awfulness of policy matters being announced publicly rather than first to this Parliament-a practice, of course, which all governments have followed from time immemorial and will go on following-specifically mentioned the Government's announcement of its revised code of conduct for Australian businessmen operating in the Republic of South Africa.

Last Tuesday I responded to a speech by Senator Missen on that subject, in which he was very critical of the revised code, arguing that it was significantly weakened compared to its predecessor. After rebutting the general theme of Senator Missen's speech, I did give notice that I would take an appropriate opportunity this week, if the time permitted, to give a more substantial and detailed reply to some of his specific criticisms. Although it is unusual for a Minister to speak in the adjournment debate, I take the course of putting this speech down now in deference to the time constraints that are upon us in this session. In further deference to the time constraints that are on us tonight, I think it might be appropriate if, rather than reading that speech, I were to seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
REPLY TO SENATOR MISSEN'S COMMENTS ON THE AUSTRALIAN CODE OF CONDUCT FOR AUSTRALIAN COMPANIES WITH INTERESTS IN THE REPUBLIC OF SOUTH AFRICA

Senator Missen originally spoke on the adjournment of 9 October 1985, drawing upon an article by Alan Fewster in the Australian of the same day which he tabled. Mr Fewster's article listed a number of changes to the text of the Code of Conduct between the original tabled by Mr Hayden on 18 April 1985 as the basis for consultation with Australian businesses operating in South Africa and the final version which was subsequently tabled by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 29 November 1985.

While a number of the specific deletions or changes reported by Mr Fewster were included in the final version tabled by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, as I said in my response to Senator Missen in the Senate on 9 October 1985, there was `no justification for the terms of the Australian story with its heading ``Government Bows on Code for South Africa'' '.

As I told the Senate on 9 October 1985, Mr Fewster's article was ``misleading'' and in a moment I shall explain in detail why this is the case, and rebut in detail the misrepresentations which Senator Missen has built upon Mr Fewster's article.

Last Tuesday Senator Missen went beyond merely saying `I told you so', to assert that what I said to the Senate on 9 October `has turned out to be entirely untrue'. Indeed, Senator Missen went on to say `I will give chapter and verse to show that it has indeed been watered down, as the article said'. Senator Missen then proceeded on a series of mischievous misrepresentations going rather beyond the terms of Mr Fewster's original article.

Nevertheless, both Mr Fewster and Senator Missen use essentially the same technique in order to achieve their misrepresentation. Namely, they report deletions and changes between the original and final versions of the text (with relatively few errors), but give a totally misleading impression by not acknowledging the way in which the matters concerned are still dealt with in the final version of the Code of Conduct.
The Code of Conduct itself begins at page 5 of the text tabled by Mr Hayden in the House of Representatives on 29 November.

At line 2 of section 2 of the Code of Conduct the expression `should abolish the practice of segregation, which is a particularly offensive form of racial discrimination' is deleted and replaced with `should integrate'. On 3 December Senator Missen claimed `I do not know what it means'. He might have taken a clue from the heading of section 2 which is desegregation at places of work. Quite obviously this is a drafting change which expresses the original meaning more succinctly and in terms of a positive course of action.

The three minor verbal changes to section 3 on employment and industrial relations practices and section 4 on remuneration are so minor that neither Senator Missen nor Mr Fewster saw fit to comment upon them.

Their misrepresentations resumed at section 5, on training and management. Both Mr Fewster and Senator Missen comment on the fact that the second sentence of the first paragraph under section 5 was deleted. This sentence read `To implement this provision fully, the educational disadvantages of non-white employees may need to be compensated for.' This sentence was removed because it contradicted the immediately preceding sentences, which in both versions of the Code of Conduct reads `Companies should appoint and promote personnel solely on the basis of their qualifications and ability.' Both Senator Missen and Mr Fewster also note the removal from the next paragraph of section 5 of the expression `facilitate and accelerate' used in relation to the movement of non-whites into more senior positions.

What they do not acknowledge is that the final version of the code requires companies to implement training and development programs `to facilitate equality of employment opportunities at all levels of the company' and to `encourage the movement of non-whites into semi-skilled, skilled, supervisory, managerial and executive positions. Non-white employees with potential for further advancement should be identified and supported to undertake outside training courses or expanded internal training programs.'

On 3 December, Senator Missen noted two deletions from section 6 of the Code which deals with labour restrictions. He noted the deletion of a reference to `aid relating to legal matters' and another deletion of a sentence which he describes as `a truism'.

However, again, Senator Missen conveys a completely misleading impression by neglecting to quote the next sentence after the deleted `truism' sentence which says `Companies should assist non-white employees and their families with advice and aid relating to legal matters to avoid infringing freedom of movement and to alleviate the deleterious effects of the migrant labour system.'

Furthermore, as I pointed out in my response to Senator Missen last Tuesday, Section 6 of the Code has been substantially strengthened by requiring Australian companies not merely to provide advice on legal restrictions on labour but to `support changes to' racially discriminatory legislation in South Africa.

The misrepresentations by Senator Missen and Mr Fewster were perhaps most substantial in relation to section 7 of the Code of Conduct dealing with quality of life. Mr Fewster claimed that the reference to `retrenchment benefits' from the earlier draft had been deleted, which it had, but he did not acknowledge that it was replaced with a reference to `contributory unemployment insurance', which is a specific mechanism for providing appropriate income maintenance.

Senator Missen went rather beyond this misrepresentation in claiming that clause (b) under section 7 of the Code of Conduct-`has all been absolutely deleted'. True, but Senator Missen did not mention that it had been replaced with a more succinct reference to all of the matters dealt with in the deleted clause (except subsidised meals). Furthermore, as I pointed out on Tuesday, that section of the final version of the Code has been strengthened by calling on companies to `set aside funds for' the measures listed.

Finally, under section 8 of the revised Code, monitoring has been substantially strengthened by the incorporation of a provision for an `independent and impartial administrator', as I noted in my responses to Senator Missen on both 9 October and 3 December.
That clearly identifies the nature of the misrepresentations which Senator Missen and Mr Fewster indulged in in their comments on the Code of Conduct.

But they also passed over the unchanged definition of the objectives of the Code because reference to them would have been inconsistent with the thrust of their claim that the Government has watered down the Code.

The intention of the Code is to go beyond the `Willesee Code' of 1974 and to provide `practical guidelines' to Australian businesses, consistent with the European community, Canadian and US Codes, within which Australian firms can voluntarily `work to eliminate discrimination on racial grounds in their South African operations', and so `help to alleviate the deprivation and hardships suffered by non-white workers' under the apartheid system.

The preamble to the Code describes some of the legal constraints which the apartheid system imposes on non-whites in South Africa and spells out Australia's opposition to that system, a posture which is consistent with our obligations under the ILO Conventions, Australia's policy on human rights and the approach of the international community to apartheid. It recognises that trade with the Republic of South Africa will continue unless the United Nations Security Council imposes comprehensive economic sanctions on South Africa, but calls upon Australian business not to exploit the special labour conditions created by the apartheid system.

Finally, there is no need to answer Senator Missen's tendentious points about publicising the Code, because they are answered in the two sentences which he quotes from Mr Hayden in making his points. It is sufficient to say that now that the Code has been finalised, `in consultation with relevant Australian interest groups', as Mr Hayden said, `the Code will be widely publicised and (he) shall issue both general and individual invitations to Australian companies to adhere to it.' There is every reason to expect that Australian business will cooperate in the implementation of the Code of Conduct, because the final version has been developed in consultation with Australian industry. The cooperative attitude of Australian industry is acknowledged in a change which was incorporated in the second paragraph of the preamble to the Code of Conduct which states that `there is no evidence that Australian companies operating in South Africa do not act as good corporate citizens.'
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 12.07 a.m. (Friday)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 28 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Attorney-General recognise the difficulties frequently encountered by homosexuals when trying to obtain normal community services, in having their relationships with their partners recognised for immigration purposes.
(2) Does the Attorney-General intend to legislate to protect the rights of these people.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The question of the recognition for immigration purposes of relationships of homosexuals with their partners is a matter for the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to consider. The honourable member is referred to the answer given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to question No. 1335 (Hansard 10 September 1985, page 585) in relation to the recognition of homosexual relationships for migration or residence status purposes. Many `normal community services' are matters which fall within the area of responsibility of State Governments. The Anti-Discrimination Act of the State of New South Wales contains provisions dealing with discrimination on the ground of homosexuality. It is the policy of the Attorney-General to encourage the State Governments to take appropriate action to protect basic human rights in areas of State concern. In areas of Commonwealth concern persons who consider they have been discriminated against on the grounds of sexual preference are entitled to complain to the Human Rights Commission, and in the case of employment under the Public Service Act, to the Merit Protection and Review Agency. Further, under the Australian Bill of Rights Bill the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission would be empowered, with the consent of the Attorney-General, to investigate complaints about discrimination in areas of State concern on the ground of sexual preference.

(2) The Government has introduced the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 to implement the provisions of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights in relation to areas of Commonwealth concern.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 20 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Attorney-General aware that the Queensland Government's Fraser Island Public Access Act (the Act), scheduled to come into operation on 1 July 1985, contains many alarming provisions including powers for any visitor in the recreation area to be fined or conscripted by any `authorized officer' without any rights of appeal or any explanation, and that the refusal of visitors to comply could lead to very heavy financial penalties and/or banishment from Fraser Island.
(2) Has the Government received complaints from user groups about the terms of the Act.
(3) Will the Human Rights Commission, as a matter of urgency, investigate the legislation and its implications for basic human rights.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) The Attorney-General is aware of the Act referred to in the honourable senator's question but is not aware of the Government as such having received any complaints about it. I am informed that the Human Rights Commission received a number of complaints but concluded that the Act was not inconsistent with Australia's obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. In the view of the Commission, the only question of human rights of any significance arising from the passing of this Act related to freedom of movement under Article 12 of the International Covenant. However the Commission concluded that, given the environmental fragility of Fraser Island, it would seem reasonable that some system of control should be placed over the movement of vehicles and people on the island in order to avoid harm to the environment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 13 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) To what extent can an Australian citizen on a very low income expect legal aid to contest a case for breach of contract in the court of a neighbouring country (e.g. Papua New Guinea).
(2) If such a person is eligible for legal aid, can he or she expect to have the costs of security met by legal aid in order to have their case heard in the court of a foreign country.

(3) Would the Attorney-General agree that 10 years is sufficient time for Australian solicitors to pursue a case of breach of contract in a neighbouring country particularly in view of the fact that the claimant has reasonable prospects of success.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney- General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As the Australian Legal Aid Office and the Legal Aid Commissions in Australia normally do not grant aid for matters to be tried before a court in another country, it is suggested that any Australian citizen requiring assistance in such a matter be advised to contact the legal aid agency in the country concerned.
(2) Refer to answer (1) above.
(3) As insufficient details have been provided of the matter to which the honourable senator is referring no comment can be made.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 19 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the 1976 Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration recommend an inquiry into the case of Mr. W. F. Toomer, former Senior Quarantine Inspector with the Western Australia Department of Health; if so, did such an inquiry take place and, what were the results of that inquiry; if not, will the Government set up such an inquiry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The 1976 Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration did recommend an inquiry into the case of Mr Toomer.

The inquiry, conducted by Messrs R. J. Perriman and G. P. Temme, officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs and Defence respectively, traversed a wide range of matters and produced a detailed report which was tabled in Parliament on 8 November 1977. The main recommendation of the report was that the proposed transfer of Mr Toomer from Western Australia to Victoria should proceed. The Public Service Board, after considering the report and consulting my Department, decided that this recommendation should be implemented, and Mr Toomer took up duty in Melbourne in January 1978.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 8 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are some organisations charging for the preparation of applications under the Community Employment Program (CEP), and that in some instances the charge levied maybe a percentage of the final fund allocated by the Government for such applications.

(2) Will the Minister investigate whether Trojan Owen and Associates deduct such payments in view of the fact that this organisation has been involved with approved CEP projects in both South Australia and Victoria. (See answer to question on notice No. 210, Hansard, 28 May 1985, p. 2666).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Some consultants who prepare applications for CEP funding on behalf of intending sponsors charge a fee for this service. Such charges are ineligible for CEP funding and must be met by the sponsor.

After a project has been approved, the sponsor may engage the consultant to manage a project and a charge is made on the basis of a fee for service. Such fees are met from the sponsor contribution to the project.

(2) Trojan Owen and Associates do not charge a fee for the preparation of project applications. Where that body is engaged to manage a project on behalf of the sponsor, a fixed fee is charged for the service. As mentioned in the answer to Question (1), these fees are met from the sponsor contribution to the project.
